Lots going on. Lovely restaurants set up around the harbour. Perfect to have some dinner and people watch. Firework demonstration every Saturday in March. It was quite spectacular.
Love it!. It's a great place for lunch or for a drink, . Beautiful views of Sydney's skyline, plenty of restaurants and cafes, Imax theatre, fireworks...Don't miss it!!

Perfect for a little stroll. Darling Harbour is wonderful for a stroll, plenty eateries and shops, my favourite is the Meat and Wine restaurant, they serve the best Ribs ever. Well worth a visit, great staff too.

Lots to do. Theres a lot to see around darling harbour, a beautiful outlook and a clean harbour and shoreline. Only a short distance from the Sydney CBD. Its un fortunate the mono rail has been discontinued and at the time of our visit there was a major building demolishion qnd construction which made the area a bit noisy
Lots to do. One place not to miss here is the aquarium. Wonderful place with lots of native fauna. Eat at one of the many cafes, Stroll along the water. Take in an Imax movie. Lots to see and do.

Darling Harbour, Sydney, Australia. If you do only one thing when you go to Australia, visit Darling Harbour and the Chinese Gardens. A little haven of tranquility in the heart of a bustling city. Fantastic.
Amazing. I really enjoyed spending time at Darling Habour. There are plenty of bads, restaurants, etc.. around.

A bit dusty.. Darling Harbour normally is a great place to visit with only a short stroll from China town. However due to demolition and rebuilding of the convention halls there is a great deal of machinery noise and building dust flying around. Thia will probably go on for months.

Great place. Though it probably is made our for the tourist didn't really seem it. Darling Harbour has an abundance of bars and restaurants with great night views of the many tall buildings across the water. Restaurants do breakfasts, lunches and dinners which are ok priced given their location.

An oasis in the city jungle. Darling Harbour has become a delightful outdoor area within the confines of Sydney. A mass of quality International restaurants are dotted throughout along with a reasonably sized shopping centre and the area easily accesses China Town and the city. A mini train ride around the area costs $5 for adults and $4 for children and lasts 25 minutes. You can hop on and off but each time it costs the same again to get back on. With the Waterfront, the shops and cafes it is a delightful spot to spend an afternoon or evening soaking up the sights and sounds of Sydney.

Wanna feel like a yokel?. Wanna feel like a yokel?Try growing up in Adelaide where we have... Let me see... One restaurant and one café by the River Torrens. Then magically transplant yourself by the power of modern air travel into the midst of Darling Harbour. Wow! Now this is a city.This is a city that knows how to relax, and relax hard. I wander around dumbstruck with my mouth open as crowds and crowds and crowds of people fill a space with noise, colour and bustle. Many are well dressed, very well dressed. All have somewhere fun to be, and appear to have come from somewhere very important. I don't really know who they all are. But I know they are all fabulously busy, important and rich.There are approximately 16 thousand billion restaurants, clubs, bars and cafés per square metre in Darling Harbour. The exact number is not known, however CERN is hard at work on the calculations.I have never seen anything like this, except the other times I've been there. High points for me are the salt smell of the harbour, my father's name on the Welcome Wall, and the Lindt girl with the French accent who could sell snow to Innuit, or chocolate sauce to me, "zhust a leetle beet, on ze side?"I wish I could stop gawping and feel like I could *ever* belong. It's amazing and I like it, but I want to go home now...
2000 milenium. I loved this place. Loads of restaurants and bars and a big club HOME had great times there. It is a great place would love to go there again. Great place!

Everyone has seen it but now you can be there. A historic area and the entrance to Sydney. Try a helicopter trip over the area to see the full huge expanse of it. Beaches surround the area as well as some very exclusive residential areas. Ferries continually travel to various stops including Manly which is definitely worth a visit.

Great. This harbour is so different from Sydney harbour. Its the up and coming place to hang out, lots of restaurants and places to eat, places to shop and boat trips as well as having the aquarium there too. The maritime museum is also here.They are doing work on the conference centre there at the moment but will look stunning once finished.

Could spend hours here. Really enjoyed spending time at Darling Harbour. The bars, cafés, the ambience, everything you could want for an enjoyable day out. The Chinese Gardens are nearby and definately worth a visit.

Great day out for everyone. I love Darling Harbour both during the day and at night. There is lots to see and do - some things for a cost, others free. You can take a picnic, get takeaway or visit a nice restaurant. There is plenty of space to sit and relax or for the kids to play in the park. You can play chess, table tennis or there are some lovely seats to sit and read or just soak up the sun. There is often a festival on, adding that special touch. Being on the water means there is always a great view. You can visit the aquarium or the maritime museum or go and watch a 3D movie at the iMax. You can even take advantage of the tranquility of the Chinese gardens. Nearby you have Chinatown and Paddy's Markets and the centre of the CBD is a quick walk.To me Darling Harbour comes alive at night. The city lights around it make it very beautiful and the views from the restaurants and hotels are superb. Would highly recommend. Just be aware that they are constructing a new convention and entertainment centre at the moment so there is some noise etc.
FUN PLACE!!!. great place to get dinner or Breaky and one of the only places that had drink specials. they had fireworks the nights we were there, very cool!!!

Fun for all!. There is so much choice here. If you're on a tight budget, you can simply stroll around on a beautiful day and soak up the atmosphere and be entertained by buskers. If your budget is more generous, you could visit some attractions such as Sydney Aquarium, Wildlife World or Madam Tussauds. Or you can take a cruise from King Street Wharf and explore Sydney Harbour and get a close up view of Sydney Harbour Bridge. If you love good coffee or desserts, then you must visit Lindt Café or Gelatissimo for delicious gelato. My favourite place is Imax where the films are a visual feast. If you park at Harbourside Carpark and see a film at Imax, you can have your parking ticket validated at Imax and park all day for a fixed nominal parking fee. Currently, there is a fireworks display every Saturday evening at 9pm at Darling Harbour, so it's a bonus if you're dining at any of the restaurants that have a view here on Saturday evenings.

A haven of choice. For the shopping enthusiast or the gourmet traveller, Darling Harbour has a spectacular array of things to see and do. From the hundreds of shops to spend those well earned dollars to a haven of choice for your palate, Darling Harbour always delivers. Entertainment in many forms throughout the day and especially at night where she comes alive with many different sounds that appeal to a diverse crowd. A must for the traveller and a popular choice for locals.
One of the greatest in Sydney!. Pretty quiet place to walk around and eat (Great burgers!!!).Also, there are plenty of attractions there, like the Aquarium and Wildlife parks.Highly recommended.
great place to visit. we have stayed at darling harbour many times it is convenient vibrant stunning. Great shopping and eateries Sydney at your door step

Worth visiting or not!. Darling Harbour has number a great restaurants and shops but take your cash / credit card with you as it's a visitors location. The view is great sitting in the sun and sipping a wine or drinking a beer and just watching the world go by. Once you've been to Darling Harbour ....you've been. It's really not one to keep going back too unless you are dining.

A great place for food and drink in Sydney.. Darling Harbour is a great location to enjoy the Sydney waterfront with a drink or meal and it also provides many entertainment and sightseeing options. From buskers to fireworks and lots of cruising options, there's something for everyone and every age at Darling Harbour. It also has a maritime museum, casino, aquarium, wildlife park and Madam Tussard's. One of my favourite places is the Lindt Chocolate Cafe at Cockle Bay - deliciously wicked treats.

Happy time, walk and food. Darling harbour has it all, food, shopping and adventure its a great place to go out for some fresh air, sit in the park and read a book, or check out whats on.Shopping and food court there too, variety of Food choices, great water views.Jet boats, ferries and lots more so many things to choose from.The only negative thing is not much shade or rain cover.re price up to you you can spend a little or spend a lot it depends on your choices.
Plenty to see around Darling Harbour. Lots to see and do here always, You can visit many times.We love the Aquarium, Powerhouse Museum, walking around on a nice day enjoying the entertainment.

place for everyone. if you just want a walk and see the Harbour, take a seat with your chips, you want a fine dining, drink a schooner of beer, have a cup of coffee/tea, go inside the museum or aquarium....really you won't get bored
Give it a go. Nice place to visit lots of eateries with some shops. We went in the morning after breakfast, so we just could not eat anymore!
Something for everyone. Darling Harbour - this has the best of everything - great shops foe the shopaholics - activities for the children - great food and icecream

Why Bother?. Rather dull...lots of over-priced shops and under-yum food. If you want to shop, head for the QVB or the Strand Arcade. To eat, almost anywhere else is better. The Aquarium is good, but that's about it.

Hub of excellence. Wonderful area. Plenty of paid parking,lots of restaurants,drinking venues and a casino. Buses,ferries and light rail can get you there from the CBD quickly and efficiently. However it is only less than one kilometer from the centre of Sydney if you feel like strolling down to it. A long climb back up to CBD.You are also close to the Sydney Fish Markets where you can relax with a seafood meal. The Maritime Museum is also there.

Great restaurants, nice views, vibrant Sydney!. Darling Harbour is a must see for visitors to Sydney. Great restaurants & cafés line the water. Usually lots of people strolling about Darling Harbour and it has a vibrant energetic feel to it. Stop in at the Lindt Cafe after dinner for a coffee/hot chocolate & dessert for a nice relaxing end to a Darling Harbour visit.

Touristy but big redevelopments at the moment.. The Darling Harbour precinct is a nice place to visit. Lots of touristy things to do and good tourist shopping. Food options everywhere and the choice is endless day or night. There is a huge redevelopment taking place at the moment (April 2014) and will be there for a while but you can easily avoid that and it wont disrupt your enjoyment. The area has lots of hotels for visitors to enjoy the views if visiting Sydney. Unfortunately they have removed the Monorail so you have to walk to the city or catch a bus from near the Maritime Museum which is adjacent to the bridge. The Casino is not far away either. A good family outing spot.

Lot's to see and do. Interesting places Maritime Museum, Pioneer Wall, Micro Brewery, Chinese Gardens, Aquarium, Harbour Cruise,Wandering 'minstrels', a vast array of eateries and much much more .Free to wander but fees for Aquarium and Chinese Gardens
Lots to see and do. Darling Harbour is a interesting place to visit. There is a maritime museum, an aquarium, and many restaurants to visit.

Hard to miss. Sydney and it's harbour are linked in beauty and variety. You don't need a lot of money to have a picnic in the Botanic Gardens and you could not find a more beautiful spot than on the grass by the harbour. Visit The Rocks and walk around the point to the renovated piers and have a coffee at one of the cafes amoungst the groovy appartments built on the piers. Watch the ships, motor cruisers and yatchets and enjoys the view. You can also jump on a ferry for Manly or the zoo.
Looking a bit old. A bit disappointed with Darling Harbour. Once the construction work is competed it may be different.

Great place to unwind after a days shopping. From one restaurant to another this is a great place to wander, eat and drink. There is a slightly more relaxed vibe compared to Circular Quay but enough activity for people watchers.

Nice walk. This is a great area to spend a few hours on a sunny afternoon/morning. There are several places for a drink and food. Shopping is touristy but ok for window shopping. The Imax is worth going too and the Chinese gardens are fantastic to go too for some peace and quiet and a cup of tea. There is a great childrens playground area if you have any children with you to spend a few hours running around.

Improving. The new developments here - play structures, water elements, restaurants etc - have been a great improvement. But all in all this is not the best place to see Sydney Harbour. It's full of tourists and seagulls and just feels dirty.

Rob's Cafe. A lot of hotels in the area offer breakfast, but if you want the best breakfast in Sydney, go to Rob's Cafe, it is just around the corner from the Pyrmont Bridge, 7/11 on one corner, just go up that road. Rob is great, friendly, always welcoming, and the food is excellent

Renovations are happening. Darling Harbour is having a major renovation, so no all parts are open. Opposite Darling Harbour is Cockle Bay which has a great choice of restaurants and bars. You can walk from Town Hall Station, are ten minute easy walk. Would'nt recommend staying in hotels close to Darling Harbour, while construction going on
Overrated, overpriced. This place is a trap for toruists, food is awful and overrated, jus go there and watch the fireworks and leave as fast as you can!
The place to be. If you don't know where to go this is the place to be. Always fun and relaxing. So much to see and feel

A Sydney Resident. As well as its many attractions , noted by other visitors, I would like to point out that Sydney has Light Rail System that connects Central Station, Paddys Markets, Darling Harbour AND a short ride to the Sydney Fish Markets. Just a few minutes between them.No matter the age of the tourist Darling harbour has something for everyone.

Beautiful view when at nigjt. Nice and beautiful view when we visit at night as we can see lightning all over the place at the harbour especially the bridge and opera house with blowing wing.It better we visit this Darling Harbour on saturday as many ocassion will happen fantastic fashion show or dressing and all type of games and music we can see or hear.Every saturday fire crackers will show at this place.
Nice view. It showcases the harbour bridge as well as the Opera house. Most people took picture of it,where you can capture in one shot the opera house and harbour bridge.

Construction Building Site. The harbour is currently under construction and is being re-built be aware if you are choosing a hotel close by to live in, as you will hear the building noise if you are staying close.

Nice place to hang out all day and night. This wharf, along with Circular Quay, reminded me a lot of my San Francisco trip from several years ago: A lot of shops, restaurants and tourist attractions all over, and worth every bit of my time. This place comes alive around sunset every evening.

So much to see and do. After visiting the Fish Markets earlier this morning, Darling Harbour is 1000 times better. I started by walking along the quay on one side of the harbour, entering a shopping complex at one point and having lunch at a Greek salad and pizza bar. Delicious! Continued my stroll along the waterfront till I came to the Maritime Museum. I didn't go in but there were plenty of boats and ships, plus a lighthouse, outside to keep me amused for about 3/4 of an hour. Then I walked back to the top of the quay, round to the other side, just browsing, enjoying the pleasant surroundings. The aquarium is at the top of this wharf, opposite the Maritime Museum. There's an I-Max theatre and of course, there are lots of tour operators waiting to take you on a Darling Harbour cruise, neither of which interested me, so from here I strolled along the quay and over to the Chinese Garden of Friendship.
Worth visiting. A place that has to be on the list. There's a lot to do and see and for all budgets. Definetly a nice place to walk and spend the day.

Parts of it being demolished. But its still good place to visit and always plenty to see. The water features throughout the area are always a great attraction for the kids to get into and get wet, theres plenty of grassed areas for them to play on. Also lots of things to see on the harbour as well as many great attractions around the waters edge. You will find plenty of seating scattered through out the park for those tired legs as well.

Walk around Darling Harbour. We were staying at the Novotel Darling Harbour hotel and went for a stroll in the evening. Plenty of restaurants and a shopping mall and live street shows. A very lively and enchanting area. There is also the national maritime museum c/w HMAS Vampire and a submarine although We did not visit this. Walked across the Pyrmont bridge . Prices are quite expensive e.g. $6 Aus for a single cone ice cream. However a great place nonetheless.

Very touristy, lots of night light. It's a great spot if you want lots of food and drink options at your fingertips, along with a few other attractions. The people watching is also great. Be sure to check into when there are fireworks...we were able to catch a nice show one night here.

Happening evening with relaxing ambience. Only walking distance (about 5-10 minutes) from my accommodation, Darling Harbour consider a next perfect place to hang out after I had early dinner knowing that there's fire crackers show at around 8.00 - 9.00pm. Would be good if there's melody played with fire crackers show. Feel so romantic accompany with happening place to hang out.Suitable for family get together especially during weekend nights.
Good hangout for the family.. Good place to spend time with family. Lots of activities for kids.. park, rides, zoo, other tourists attractions.

Great!. There are many restaurants in various specialties! You can just walk around and take pictures or enjoy visiting the great Maritime Museum and eat good food in one of restaurants around. There are many activities for kids and places for jogging. Nice visit!

Nice place to spend an evening out. Nice area for lots of dining choices. Several street performers were present on the afternoons and evenings we were there. I felt safe walking in the area. Great harbor views.

Pyrmont Bridge is just beautiful. I don't know why I simply love the Pyrmont Bridge. The colour flags always change according to events but they are always so pretty. The place is always live though lazy yet not crowded. Combine this with a visit to the Seafood Market! Nice additional to my personal travel journal on blogspot. Highly recommended as sidebar to business trip as it is in city center and does not take much time.

A great harbour. There are some amazing boats and yachts that pull up into Darling Harbour, and of course there are battleships and ferries too. At night, the backdrop of Darling Harbour is amazing, and it reminds me much of Marina Bay in Singapore, though not quite as inspiring. There are lots of eateries and bars around Darling Harbour, much of it very expensive, although there's also a Starbucks and a McDonald's nearby. Cockle Bay Wharf was my favourite part of the Harbour.
Good place to visit. Lots to see here and many places to eat, but we personally preferred Circular Quay. Certainly worth a visit though.

Brilliant Fireworks. We walked down here after a meal on Saturday night as I'd picked up that there would be a fireworks display at 9pm. Obviously very popular spot with lots of nice bars, big hotels on the north side, and the Sydney Aquarium sited here too. Very picturesque, ferries also leave from here as well as the main spots on Circular Quay. And the fireworks were brilliant.

Great place to visit - So much to see and do. I hadn't been to Darling Harbour for many years and it has got even better! So much to see and do. Well set up with many places to eat and places to visit. Very social and friendly scene. Darling Harbour at night is amazing, looking at sights/lights over the city is pretty cool. Very easy to get to from central trains and only a short walk. A must when visiting Sydney.

Great harbour with good attractions. Home to madame tussards, the sydney aquarium and the maritime museum we had a great time at darling harbour. There are also shopping centers there with food courts to eat. We had to come back in 2 separate days to view all the attractions. My advice is to ride the ferry from circular quay or take the light rail from Central station. Just a stone's throws away is the Star casino as well.

Come for the food and water views. Enjoyed the stroll by the harbour. Had our dinner and lunches in the numerous restaurants and cafes. Some construction going on at the moment as they are tearing down the adjacent Sydney Convention Centre and replacing it with another.

Like Fisherman's Wharf. Build for tourists, but a nice activity on a warm evening. Visit the submarine and destroyer at the National Maritime Museum as well as the Sydney Aquarium. We had good food and it worked well for grandparents and a tem year old.

Chilled out area of Sydney. Darling Harbour is set just a mile from the ferries and to the city centre and ideally sited to visit for the tourist with its range of hotels, busy cafés and bars along the water, shopping centre, metro rail station and cinema. It's a really clean and bustling area with lots going on and a perfect place to visit.

A big surprise; many attractions, very impressive!. A main ferry stop from Circular Quay, this development is very modern and includes the Sealife Aquarium ( v good ), National Maritime Museum ( incl berthed vessels ) , Zoo, Pyrmont bridge, lots of cafes. Great views over the water to the other side of the harbour. A "train" will take you around the harbour for a small fee. Interesting architecture.

Too expensive. This is one expensive place to visit, found the Museum the best value, food and drink prices are just plain rip off, I was wondering how a Family of Mum Dad and 4 kids could ever afford to go there in particular the Aquarium that is very costly, we gave it a miss,
Great hive of activity. You can do so much in this area. Many restaurants and cheap too. I had lunch for just $10. absolute bargain!

A great day even if the sun isn't shining. Plenty of great attractions housed in the confines of the Harbour from the gorgeous Chinese Gardens to the Sydney Aquarium and Powerhouse Museum. On a sunny day this is a great pace to wander and to sit in the sun enjoying great coffee or food - and you are spoiled for choice in terms of good quality restaurants and bars (some a little pricey). Kid friendly and lots of happy smiling faces.
Love that place... Darling Harbour...... 1 of my favorite places to hang out in Sydney... great caf��s great restaurants, wonderful food... great atmosphe... just wonderful....

A great place!. Go to Darling Harbour in a Saturday, when it's at its utmost: lots of people, street artists, music, very nice bars and restaurants, not to mention the Maritime Museum. Don't forget to make a reservation for the Saturday evening in one of the bars and restaurants (at the veranda, of course) for the fireworks. You'll love it!!!

Well worth a visit. Visited here out of curiosity as part of a ferry tour of the river. Glad we did even though it is a bit touristy but it was worthwhile even just seeing the old sailing ships etc. All of these areas take advantage of the tourists so if you are looking for cheap visitor attractions you can avoid places like Darling harbour and The Rocks. We would definitely come back just for the atmosphere.

Firework display at the weekend too!. there is a relatively small shopping mall, but mostly this is an area of eateries. We had a very nice meal here tho. Be aware that there is significant development going on currently with the demolition and re building of the conference centre, with forms part of the harbour. Still a nice area to visit tho.

Shopping, aquarium and plenty of choices for food. We spent a great day here eating brunch, picking up a few souvenirs, eating seafood, as well as visiting the aquarium which was well worth a couple of hours of out time! It is obviously a touristy area but relaxed and with a great setting overlooking the water.

Definitely a tourist trap.. The harbour has plenty to see and do, but beware that almost all restaurants and shops raise their prices correspondingly.
Eat love pizza, by the imax theatre is the best value here, with a 'large' pizza and drink for under 20 dollars.

Lots To see and Do. Got off the Hop-On-Hop-Off at Darling Harbour. This is a great place for families looking for lots to do, but not too conducive if you want to spend time quietly just enjoying the sights. To busy for that It seemed strange to see all the Christmas decorations and no snow. they certainly did a good job of making it Christmasy looking, and i could see the kids loved the place.

Worth a trip. Lots going on with boat rides (exhilarating even if a little scarry!) Super food outlets, aquarium and just lots of areas just to people watch. Visit the Chinese garden for an oasis of peace where you can also dress up in traditional costume if the fancy takes you.

Don't miss the fireworks!. Splendid view during the day, fabulous fireworks at 09:00pm! Just make sure you arrive there a bit earlier to grap a good viewing spot as it can get really crowded some times. Worth it the wait
Daaaarling!. Darling Harbour is brilliant. an eclectic mix of dining, bars, playgrounds for kids, IMAX theatre and just a great atmosphere.

Another Aspect of Sydney. We were at Darling Harbour 3 times - for lunch, for an evening stroll, and getting off a harbour tour. It is very pleasant and clean. We expected more "street-type" entertainment, but it was more quiet and peaceful. There are at least 3 easy pedestrian walkways from the CBD that we found to get there (so there must be more than that) and all felt very safe.
Darling Harbour. Plenty to do around Darling Harbour, there is the Maritime Museum, The Sydney Aquarium, The Chinese Gardens are so tranquil, plenty of fun for the kids and plenty of eating places
One of the things to do. Boardwalk with huge selection of restaurants and bars. Diverse selection of food. Great people watching.
Wonderful. I walked all around Darling Harbour, saw the maritime museum, and enjoyed the life and all the events on the pier.

Exciting first view of Sydney. This was where we had our first beer in Australia so it has to be something special. There is so much to see around the harbour, good walkway leading back to the city, plenty of good restaurants although Sydney is not the cheapest place in the world to eat out! But every meal was good, every coffee excellent and every beer ice-cold. What more could you want? A few sculptures thrown in, ships and museums side by side, just a lovely place to stroll.

The place to be when you are in Sydney. Finally am here at the Darling Harbour and now I fully understand its popularity. Right by the sea, Darling Harbour is filled with beautiful restaurants and cafes, great place to be to people watch while enjoying a good cup of coffee or have a lovely dinner with a magnificent view. Nice to bring the family here for a casual stroll by the sea.

nice and cool evening stroll. Travel during late summer, but the weather for the evening is cool, lots of seagull also resting by the jetty. many families, friends and couples strolling by the harbour. Relaxed

People Watching Paradise. Darling Harbour is one of the prime attractions of Sydney so it's perfect for people-watching. Escape the city - stroll around the water's edge checking out the cafes and parks.

Busy Tourist Stop. Lots to see and do, IMAX, lots of eating places, bars, some shopping, as well as the aquarium and many other activities. It is just a good place to go sit and people watch with some good food at places like Nicks close by. You can hop on the ferry by the aquarium to Circular Quay for six dollars each way and this is well worth doing to visit the Rocks, the beige and Sydney Opera House which are all worth doing.I would say that DH is looking tired now and renovation work is going on in the area but this will not effect your visit.
A great and happening place. A great place and so much going on - great restaurants and atmosphere - so many different restaurants.

Great vibe!. We stayed near the harbour and very much enjoyed strolling around both during the day and in the evening - so much going on. The skyline is impressive and we were fortunate to be visiting when there was a firework display on our first evening. China town is nearby as well as a Darling Quarter with great restaurants and a water themed park for children opposite(although the adults loved it too!) . They even had an open air screening of Chicago. There is a large visitor centre just behind the IMAX cinema, as well as plenty of shops and more restaurants. We also caught a boat from the harbour to get to the zoo a which was really handy. And of course just a stroll around the harbour or across the bridge takes you into the heart of the city in just a few minutes.

Great Place. Lots to see and do,visit the Chinese gardens and try their tea,well worth a visit....loads of Restaurants that cater for different tastes...Wildlife Zoo is there as well for the kids. Casino is just a stroll away and do a great buffet at a reasonable price...street artists to amuse you...and the Ferries and private charters to take you into the bays around the harbour.....Saturdays nights at 9 are the regular fireworks display.. a must see...loved it all.

Buzzing. A different feel to Circular Quay this is worth a visit too! It is lively whatever time of day and Cockle Bay is bursting with restaurants and bars. The Imax is worth a visit and you also have the aquarium, madame tussauds and the zoo to choose from. A short walk takes you right into the heart of Sydney's shopping mecca.First Saturday of the month there is a fab local growers market - delicious foods to try - just behind The Star at Pyrmont and well worth a visit.

Beautiful place with great food. Stayed at the 4Points which itself wasn't a spectacular hotel, but it's right downtown and walking distance to the harbour. Darling harbour was a very nice place to stroll and people watch, with many restaurants and live entertainment at several of the restaraunts. Sydney Darling harbour area is quite expensive compared to other cities in Australia, but the atmosphere and quality/selection of food was worth the higher cost. The IMAX at the harbour has the "worlds largest screen" if you happen to get a rainy day it was a great experience.

Much improvements going on!. Visited Darling Harbour last year and was pleasantly surprised to see the continuing improvements since then.This is fast becoming a tourist destination in its own right and major refurbishment is currently being undertaken at the Entertainments Centre which will make this a oremiert venue.The Chinese garden is well worth a visit and for those with small children there is a good splash park and play area just behind the harbour. Further still behind are the shops and well established Paddy's Markets open most days.

For entertainment, dining, fireworks: a must do. We walked to Darling Harbour from our CBD lodging...less than 15 min. Waterfront dining at a myriad of establishments. Lots of people there on a Saturday night, sidewalk music entertainers. A fun place overall. Fireworks Saturday night at 9 p.m. add a nice touch. Daytime attractions, too, although we didn't partake of them. Highly recommend.
A little tired. We didn't enjoy this as much as we thought we would it was a little tired. We felt that the only reason to go here was to get to the fish markets.
Beautiful location for a dinner. I had dinner here on 2-3 occasions while in Sydney on holiday. Highly recommended. Variety of restaurants and cafes to chose from.
Great restaurants. A very good choice of places to eat. Happy hour is busy, so worth the effort to get there early! Fireworks on each Saturday night are spectacular

Something for everyone. Something for everyone at this spectacular place. Foods from around the world meet at Darling Harbour, so something for everyone. The prices are very reasonable and various happy hours give value for money. The free firework show every Saturday night is well worth seeing.

A day out for fun. Its always nice to go for a day out to Darling Harbour. The food court always has good for for lunch and you can choose to sit inside out of the heat or enjoy the view and sit outside.

Free fireworks show. Great place to people watch and to just chill out. Lots of places to eat. Go to McDonalds and buy a soft serve cone for 30 cents, absolute bargain. Catch the 555 bus from George street, it's free. Walk to the Chinese markets.

Great tourist spot. If you are in Sydney, do not miss Darling Harbor. It has everything that a tourist is looking for such as scenic view, good restaurants and shops. It is also a walking distance to China town. If you are travelling with elderly, ride the "Chu Chu train". This trains covers the entire Darling Harbor.
Sydney is beautiful. Darling Harbour is greate if you are midtown and don't want to trek up to Circular Quay. Plus it has more restos, attractions and close to Chinatown and Paddy's Market.

Nothing much to do.... There is nothing much to do at Darling Harbour itself, but it is linked to the other side of the city with shops and restaurants so it becomes a "must-go" place.
There are ferries departing from the piers regularly so it may be convenient if you know where the ferries bring you to.
Fantastic location. Spent most afternoons down at Darling Harbour in the many bars and restaurants that dominate the harbour wharf. Loads to see and do and very reasonably priced.

Wonderful visit. We stayed at the Novotel and it was perfect for all the restaurants at Darling harbour. The hop on hop off bus stops here, there is the ferry to Circular Quay. Across Pyremont bridge and you are in the centre of town. Plus the maritime Museum. Perfect.

Scenic place with great eateries.. The view from darling harbour is awesome, and there is the best ribs (hurricane's Grill) & best Fish & chips (Blue Fish) along the harbour too!
A recommendation is to go to circular quay first and take a ferry ride down to darling harbour.
Darling Hourbour for food. Lots of restaurants and cafes. Big shopping mall with a food hall, the Nautical Museum is here. The tram from central station goes there but you can walk.
great place to eat. Many restaurants and attractions. The best restaurant was Nicks Seafood. The Tapas Restaurant had a limited menu but was good.

Lots to see and do but expensive. Lots around here from restaurants to museums. Nicely put together but it all feels a bit twee and expensive. Worth a ferry trip and a coffee but that was about it for us.

DARLING HARBOUR. Wow . . . . what can I say. . . . It was the Saturday night before Christmas 2013,
Went to the Firework display. . . . it only lasted about 5 minutes.

Beautiful spot, plenty to see and do. Darling Harbour was celebrating the month of love, with crazy themed entertainments. There are lovely cafes all round it to choose from, so one can eat out of doors with a lovely view of the boats coming and going and, of course, people watch.

Loved this place one of the highlights of my trip to OZ. I loved this place busy bustling and relaxing at the same time lovey places to eat lovely place to take a long walk with that someone special in your life,the fireworks display on a Saturday night while we were having dinner was just spectacular.The street performers were a great source of entertainment,just a great place to chill relax watch the world go by
Loved the Harbour. I loved that fact that i could walk there from our hotel and it had lights that made me feel safe even when i was out at night on my own.

Absolutly my favourite place. Darling harbour is beautiful to walk round, theres loads of restaurants to choose from and shopping centre, a beautiful play area for kids, the sealife center and wildlife park, every weekend they have fireworks, I really enjoyed spending time here.

best place in sydney - so much to do i have to go back. wildlife, sealife, wax museum, food, shops, entertainment, ferries and movies and i'm sure there is more.Free shows at night time - just grab something to eat and listen and watch the free shows!!! So much to do - i missed out on too much going back to make sure i finish and digest as much as possible.By far my favourite place in Sydney.
Watch this space. It's all being remodeled at the moment - ask me again when it's all done. There was a Thai market/festival on at the time but we could not hang about to see it at its best.

Lots to do for Tourists with Lots of Attractions. We didn't do any shopping at Darling Harbour but it looked like there was plenty to be done.Lots of tourist attractions including a Wildlife place.Madame Tusauds and Sea Life.Expensive but good way to spend the day

So much to do. Darling Harbour is arguably more scenic than circular quays... yep. Darling Harbour genuinely lives up to its name, as it is really quite the ideal area to take a leisurely walk around with a loved one or friends. Very scenic during the daytime, we went in a scorching summer day and the short walk from the Star down to Darling harbour was something to behold. Great breeze across the bridge, while you go past ample amounts of bars and restaurants along Cockle Bay Wharf (although far too pricey), you can enjoy a few drinks especially during happy hours. On my second night on the wharf, we were treated to an open mic night and an impromptu fireworks display.there are lots of other attractions nearby - including the largest IMAX cinema and gorgeous "sinking fountain" which is great fun to try and walk down without getting your feet wet (we failed!). There are often street performers there who are masters of their art. We were treated to a comedic axe wielder. (I cant believe i just typed that)Make sure you walk toward the chinese garden of friendship for some down time and reflection. Definitely one of my absolute favourite places in Sydney!!!

Enjoyable Day. Enjoyed a meal here and went to Madame Tussauds and the zoo. Not impressed with the zoo as it was all one way. As we entered they announced a talk on the koalas which were near the exit and not easy to get in time. If you are planning to go to Queensland or South Australia were you are allowed to hold koalas not pay to be photographed looking at a koala not worth the price.Darling Harbour has a light display in the run up of the New Year fireworks so good spot, doesn't fill up as quickly as by the brifge.

Was great to visit. The Darling harbour is one of the most popular places in Sydney, it has various restuarants, and family venues . Unfortunately, when i was there, it was raining all day so i was not able to spend much time admiring the harbour, had to stay in most of the time but surely on a sunny day, it would be lovely to visit. Don't miss it !

Waterfront Activity Center. There is so much going on at Darling Harbour, you can spend all day and all night. Large number of restaurants overlooking the water. Music and entertainment and museums are available. Fireworks are not to be missed. Make sure you are on the bridge when a large boat comes through to see how it passes. Great place to also just relax and people watch!

Lots to do and see. Lots of restaurants, waterside walks, a splendid bridge, shopping mall, (if you really must have one), and, of course, an excellent aquarium, zoo, maritime museum, and more.Saturday night is fireworks night so get there well before 21:00hrs!
Great place to shop & eat. I spent the most of a couple of days around the harbour area and found plenty of good touristy shops and lots of good cafes with a great choice of food and wine

Not to be missed. A nice place to spend a few hours. Plenty of eating places to suit all budgets. Also an Imax cinema and Maritime Museum on hand, not forgetting all manner of boats and ships on display.

Huge harbor. We walked all the way around the harbor. There are many restaurants with outdoor patios, an aquarium, hop on-hop off boat tours, movie theater, even a little train to transport you around the harbor. We saw the Saturday night fireworks display. Day or night it's a destination not to be missed.

Darling. Plenty to do at Darling. Shopping, restaurants, IMAX, etc. We happened to be there as they were setting up for Australia Day and we enjoyed watching the activity in the harbor. Had dinner and saw a movie on what is billed as "the world's largest IMAX screen. Well worth visiting.

The place to hang out. Amazing restaurants and bars, which can be a little pricey, but the view is stunning. Went in February and in the lead up to valentines day had the most amazing firework display for 10 minutes on Friday and Saturday nights all for free. Even showed old films in the little park which you just sit down and watch.
comercial. bit expensive and glitzy grubby for a focal point of the city - not my cup of tea but you must pay a visit

One of the must see's in Sydney. I came here almost everyday while vacationing in Sydney. There are tons of restaurants, shops, Sealife, maddam tussads. You can also catch the Captain Hook hop on hop off ferry. The views are nice and this place really lights up at night.

Great place to spend a day!. There are several attractions in the harbor area including the Maritime Museum, Aquarium, and Wildlife World. We were there during the Dragon Boat races and the Valentine's Day fireworks, so we also had plenty of free entertainment.There are numerous good restaurants around the harbour, but be prepared for sticker shock at some of them. If you're just looking for something light (and cheaper) there are several choices for sandwiches and salads in the food court. The Harbourside Shopping Centre has various shops for everything from toiletries to souvenirs.

Worth a visit but very expensive to eat or drink & noisy. Great for people watching, observing the Ibis birds with their long curved beaks and walking through. Sadly whilst we were there they were demolishing the old Convention Centre which was constructed from reinforced concrete, this created a lot of background thud thud thud as the hammer drills (like jack hammers) cut through the very large building. Personally I could not see a great deal wrong with the building but I guess they ve their reasons for knocking it down.

Favourite place in Sydney. Title says it all really - super place to spend the day just kicking back and relaxing, plenty to do around the area and great if your idea of relaxation is sitting back, drinking coffee and people watching!
A bit overdone. We have enjoyed going there 2 times - both different. Bit of a tourist trap but some reasonable place to enjoy. Auckland and Falmouth beat it each time.

Always something going on. Darling Harbour is a place I go to when I need to occupy some time in Sydney ... there is always something going on. Most obvious are the many tourist attractions and restaurants/bars/cafes ... which are just lovely, but can cost a lot of money. However, if you look around, there is often something fee or cheap ... buskers, films, art installations, or places to sit and watch the goings on.

Cosmopolitan and vibrant. Great atmosphere, there always seems to be something going on. Many restaurants and bars plus shops. Other attractions include IMAX cinema, Maritime Museum, Aquarium, Wildlife Centre and Madame Tussauds plus ferries and harbour cruises to many locations. The main Sydney shopping streets are a short walk away.

Fun by ferry or walking. We walked from Circular Quay and took the ferry there..both are lovely and give you different views of Darling Harbour. Good options for Happy Hour but check around for the specials and hours.

Fabulous. Love Darling harbour an absolutely beautiful part of Sydney. Take a wander round the water, see the old navy ships or grab a coffee & just relax. Stroll round the casino, try your luck with a dollar. If wanting to buy some cheap goodies head to Paddy's markets a treasure trove of great bargains. Well worth a couple of hours while in Sydney.

Love the view. Surround by lots of restaurants and some tourist area such as Imax theatre, Sydney Aquarium, Madame Tussaud and etc made this place was worthed to visit. Too bad, i arrive in sydney when the monorail was already closed, but had good late lunch at one of the restaurant and have a good walk to explore the area.
Fun and lots of eating places. Darling Harbour has a lot to offer in the way of food and entertainment. You can also catch the ferry here to almost anywhere you want to go.
Tourist Area. Typical Tourist area. Many shops and stores selling sometimes over priced goods.The restaurants were good and served up large portions but were very expensive.
Lovely Place. We arrived for a late lunch ended up staying for supper!So much to do,some nice restaurants,IMAX ,they even had Fireworks at night that was the icing on the cake! Will recommend f

Love this place. Absolutely loved Darling Habour. there was always something to do and somewhere different to eat. So many places in the area you could spend an entire day here. there was a huge playground behind the main harbour, would be great for the kids. IMAX theatre, a shopping centre and also a short walk to Chinatown and the Chinese garden of friendship. The aquarium and wildlife park are in the harbour as well as madame tussauds. Catch the ferry from circular quay here you wont regret it!

If Carlsberg did play parks.... It would be hot, sunny, with swings and zip slide.Chutes under shade, band playing (not busking).Toilet, cafés and shops within a few steps. A play stream and splash park to cool off in.Find it behind IMAX theatre, Darling Harbour. Ideal for 3-5 year olds.

Perfect picture postcard. At any time of the day, Darling Harbour is absolutely beautiful, but you can spend more time there comfortably in the evenings. The sea gulls, the picturesque blue water, the cruise ships and the city's skyline against a setting sun look gorgeous. There are several cafeterias and lots of shopping to do by the sides. There are many 'living statues', street artists and singers providing entertainment. By dusk, as the city's lights start coming up, the place looks like a fairyland. Even at the height of summer, the harbour side is cool and breezy in the evenings. A must-see for tourists and a lovely venue for Sydneysider families during weekends.

Great Atmosphere. Darling Harbor has a great atmosphere with loads of restaurants and bars. There are also loads of activities. I only wish there was more public seating under shelter. It was raining the day I went and there really wasn't any cover except in a restaurant.

Beautiful at nightime.... Everytime i am Sydney i visit Darling harbour for dinner, i love the lights and clean surroundings and if you are lucky to be there on Saturday night, the fireworks are great!I think Darling Harbour is much more beautiful than Sydney Harbour itself, all tourists should visit.
a bit too commercialised for me but lots to do.. The museums and sealife centre etc are well worth a visit, but the atmosphere was a little too commercialised for me. I must be getting old!

Wow this has gone downmarket!. Ten or so years ago this was an exciting place to come to with the family, now it's sadly tacky. Cookie-cutter restaurants on Cockle Bay wharf, difficult to distinguish between them; annoying music everywhere (don't they know people have iPhones now if we want to hear music?), harbourside shopping mall looking tired too. They're demolishing the convention centre, I hope they fix up the rest of the harbourside too; it's such a great location, spoiled by lack of investment, apart from a few logos stuck around the place. Needs to get its act together, and soon.

Darling Harbour is a Darling spot. We were in Sydney leading up to Valentines Day and the harbour was done in a really romantic theme - with little boats for couples to go out on, there was love songs being played all over the harbour and then there was the most magic fireworks display ever - with beautiful red hearts appearing in the sky...Well Done, Darling Harbour...
So much to do. A wonderful little train takes you to Darling harbour, and the you can wander,shop,eat and drink until you need to sleep. The diversity of food is amazing, A must if in Sydney.

Darling Harbour Sydney. Good choice of bars and restaurants, there are also many shops to look at by the bridgeThis is less expensive than Sydney Harbour For info, they also have fireworks, and we saw a great display on Christmas Eve
Modern. Its a modern marina style development so how much you like it depends on what you think of modern marina style developments!I'm happy to give it a miss when I'm in Sydney.

Definitely for those who like "touristy" locations.. I should have scanned the hotels in the area and known what to expect. Had I come to Sydney and only seen Darling Harbour, I would have never come back to Australia. While I had a delicious steak at I'm Angus, the entire experience felt like I was at a grand food court at an outdoor mall. If you want to see thousands of people while you eat a steak, or have lunch at Baia where the rigatoni pasta was without flavor - this is your spot. Remember, you will also wait like you are waiting behind a thousand people. At I'm Angus, I never saw my server after he took my order. I gave my complimentary dessert coupon to the table next to me. It wasn't worth the wait.There are plenty of activities for families, and there are thousands of families. They are ready for you, and will charge for photos, keychains, etc. Bring your wallet.Had I not spent the first four days at the Westin, near the Four Seasons and the upscale mall, I truly would have been disappointed with my trip. Thankfully I only booked this area for an overnight stay. They have nothing to worry about with my review. This is built and designed to hold convention center crowds. And they will keep coming for sure... One more positive - I stood next to a Koala bear and he posed for a photo.

It just gets better and better. I've watched Darling harbour evolve over the last 30 years and I have to say it just gets better and better. Love the new water play thing they've put in for kids - stylish, practical and very effective. Plus they've managed to keep some of the good old landscaping thats been there since I was a child. Well worth the visit if you've never been and a nice day out for those who have been before as there are loads of things to do in this area.

World class entertainment precinct. With dozens of restaurants, kids water play area, playground, park areas, shops, marina etc, Sydney aquarium, theatre and more this precinct caters to families, singles, couples and I've also been to business meetings and functions. It is a beautiful area not to be missed.
better than sydney harbour. more shop and attraction. more restaurant and happening. better than sydney harbour. easily to get around
Beautiful place. Such a lovely place to go to have drinks and a good view. Get down there on a Saturday for the fireworks,
Lovely walk. . Great place for a walk and great spot for pictures. During the sunset the buildings get an amazing color with the reflex of the sun.There are plenty of options of bars and restaurants.

Great entertainment hub in Sydney. A lively harbour side precinct, Darling Harbour is just a 10-minute walk from Sydney city Centre. Located just west of the Sydney city Centre, it is accessible by Monorail, Bus, Light rail or Ferry, or just a short walk from the Sydney CBD (Centre) or our Chinatown. I took ferry from Circular Quay Wharf. Journey time is 25 minutes. Return ferry fare is 14.80 AUD. One of Sydney's largest dining, shopping and entertainment precincts has a full calendar of outdoor events as well as one of the city's most restful spots, the Chinese Gardens of Friendship.King Street Wharf is a prime nightspot, packed with sleek dining establishments and funky nightclubs. Cockle Bay Wharf offers waterfront promenades with alfresco cafes, bars and restaurants. Some of Sydney's most popular attractions are here; SEA LIFE Sydney Aquarium and WILDLIFE Sydney. Darling Harbour has fun for kids and the whole family. Madam Tussauds Museum is also there in Darling Harbour. You can find a whole array of things to do for kids, such as the Sydney Aquarium and the new Sydney Wildlife Center, to mention a few. The IMAX Theatre shows features daily on their gigantic screen. The Powerhouse Museum has a vast array of hands on displays and kids activities to try. The Australian National Maritime Museum has ships, boats and sometimes submarines for kids to clamber on. The shopping caters from authentic Australian at the Gavala National Aboriginal Cultural Centre to fashion, jewellery, gifts and souvenirs. Opal shoppers will be delighted by the array of choices available.Thousands of exhibits relate Australia’s history from ancient times when Aboriginal people trapped fish and traded with Asian neighbors, right up to the present at the Australian National Maritime Museum.See what life was like on the convict ships - how Australia rode on the whale’s back, how our first submarine fought bravely (and lost) at Gallipoli, what people packed when they sailed to a new life on these shores, why surfboards have become shorter- and much more.Review the fleet! Board Vampire, the former Australian Navy destroyer and last of its big gun ships. A free guided tour will take you down below to see how the crew lived, worked and relaxed. Darling Harbour is a Centre for nightlife, dance the night away or enjoys a cocktail while taking in the water views, there are bars, pubs and restaurants to try. Sydney Aquarium with the largest collection of Australian marine life, some dangerous, all beautiful. Try and take the time to see the new Wildlife Centre with all kinds of Australian fauna. The Powerhouse Museum - Sydney’s Distinguished and Largest Museum.

Vibrant Area. There is always something going on in Darling Harbour, whether it be street theatre, a full blown exhibition, people watching or enjoying a brilliant fish meal. This is one place that show be on every itinery of people visiting Sydney. WHile there make an effort to look out the Chinese Garden, and enjoy the tranquility of a chinese garden amongst the mayhem of the area.

Love it. Much to do and see, many very nice restaurants for all tastes.Walking around och in my case wheelchair, and just enjoying the people and the atmosphere. No problems moving around whith the wheelchair.

Visit on Saturday~. Darling Harbour is a commercial place surrounded with many cosy restaurants. There is fireworks in every Saturday 9pm.It's great to chill by the sea while watching the beautiful fireworks
Smaller that Sydney Harbor bur just as worthwhile. this is a lovely harbor known for its' seafood restaurants, the aquarium and more. Definitely worth a visit.

Darling Harbour. Very pretty walk with lots of shops, also activities like children playing soccer. Restaurants were very busy and okay for a snack and a glass of wine, but we were very disappointed in the meal that we had at Hurricane's!

Very sophisticated. Although smaller and not so busy Darling Harbour still has all the charm and exuberance that you come to expect from Australian harbours. The only minus is that it is expensive to eat there, but if you do it will not disappoint.

Lots to do!. There are lots of restaurants, bars and there is a big cinema here.
There are a few street perfomers and things going on near the water feature to entertain kids etc.
Very picturesque and worth a nice walk around and over the bridge.
There are fireworks every Saturday night which is fabulous to watch with a wine in hand :)

Vibrant night life. Well worth a visit for a night. Bars restaurants and clubs, and for those not looking for those things, fireworks (night dependant) and street performers make this place worth a visit.

Take a Ferry to Darling Harbour for a Fun Visit. This is a great little harbour full of great pubs, restaurants, and outside activities. There are free fireworks every Saturday night during the summer months, so we were able to take those in as well. We had a day pass for the ferry system, so were able to do both Manley and Darling in the same day/evening.

Great Eateries and attractions.. We walked from Potts Point down through the Botanic Gardens around the Rocks and all the way to Darling Harbour. Quite a walk but excellent for seeing all there is of this area.
what alot to be seen.. Variety of things to be seen here lots of cafes and places to look at and lovely walk around it a beautiful atmosphere very popular site.
My favourite Sydney destination. Every visit to Sydney wouldn't be the same without going to darling harbor for drinks and great food with the most beautiful views ans spectacular night lights

A little overrated for me, but I can see the appeal for others. It's a very modern, eating and entertainment focussed space. If that's your kind of thing then Darling Harbour does it really well. To me it's quite sterile and lacks soul and character.

Lots of restaurants; great views. The Darling Harbour is a stop on the hop on hop off bus. We hopped off and had a wonderful lunch and beer at one of the cafés with beautiful views of the harbor and the sunshine. It is a great place to stroll not too far from the central business district.

scenic and beautiful. Lovely to just stroll around ,enjoy the views and food. We visited the National Maritime Museum and the Chinese Gardens. Both well worth it! A generous seniors card discount entry in both venues.
I bet it was great before all the tourists. Lovely spot with lots of action. Some very good restaurants and nightlife. The fireworks show is one of the best I have seen.

Boats, shops, food, James Craig,Maritime Museum!. Wow! so much to see and do and all close together. The James Craig was magnificent sailing ship and to see it up close and go onboard and see how immigrants and ancestors travelled over the seas is quite humbling. Maritime museum has a large variety of boats moored along side it's building and the immigrants wall is filled with names of all those who have arrived in Sydney Harbour from far and wide. A nice array of places to eat and drink with water lapping the docks and music playing. Great place for families!

Loved it. We had a hotel close to the harbour and was easy to walk to, the atmosphere on an evening was brilliant just strolling around looking at the impressive skyline. Watching the street performers we took a water taxi tour and saw the harbour bridge in all it's glory and the opera house well worth the time.

Excellent Restaurants -. The choice of restaurants is just amazing - shopping is not great, but the atmosphere of Darling Harbour with all the people, views of the city, the old bridge and ferry, but it's the choice of restaurants - just Awesome -

Darling Harbour. It will take you more than a day to see all the sights in Darling Harbour. You have the Maritine Museum, Aquarium, Imax, Wildlife park and Madam Tusauds. There are literaly a couple dozen + bars and eating areas looking onto the harbour at various prices. Darling Harbour is only a short 3 block walk from the Queen Victoria Shopping Mall where you can catch the train to anywhere in the city. This mall is within a very old historic building, worth a wander.
A happening spot!. Lots to do. The Maritime Museum was the highlight for us. Just happened to be there for the rowing competition which was fun to watch. Plenty of restaurants and shopping.

Lovely location. We visited Darling Harbour and stayed at the Ibis hotel over the New Year period. Most nights we dined out in the many restaurants that can be found there. We also went to the Imax cinema.

What a place!. My partner and I wanted accommodation on at The Rocks and were a little disappointed when all we could afford was a place just outside Darling Harbour, but man were we wrong. In our opinion Darling Harbour is way better than the Rocks. There are tones of restaurants boasting all different cuisines from Thai to Spanish to Italian to Japanese and Australian grills. My partner and I were lucky enough to come to Darling Harbour during their Month of Love celebrations. They have lots of live performances in the evening and have strung up large balloons and lights shaped like hearts in the harbour in dedication to the month. At night the harbour was offering love boat rides on little row boats which were decorated in flowers and hearts. For $25 we got to row around for an hour - it was so romantic! They even had large white hearts anchored in the harbour so they floated on the surface of the water. At night they offered impressive firework displays to romantic music absolutely free it was such a romantic night i will remember forever! If you have time go this month to enjoy the love month celebrations!

Lots to see and do. Darling Harbour is very smart and is nearby by lots of attractions including the Zoo and Wildlife World, you could happily spend a day here. Plenty of eateries and shops to cater for all tastes/budgets. I really liked the Maritime Museum which had outdoor as well as inside exhibits.

Full of tourist atracttions. In the Darling Harbor you have three of a combo of attractions commonly offered to tourists: Sydney Aquarium, Wild Life Sydney and Madame Tussauds Museum. I bought the combo through the internet and I received a huge discount. After the visits you can go eat in any restaurant in the harbour and enjoy the view. The Darling Harbour is a walking distance from the Sydney CDB. Definitely it worths a visit.

Array of boats and ships. Maybe not as notoriously famous as Circular Quay or Woolloomooloo, Darling Harbour is one of the places in Sydney where you realize that this city is, on top of everything else, one of the largest harbours in the world. Walk around and enjoy the variety of boats and ships, you can take nice photos of them with all the Sydney skyscapers in the background. There's even a museum.

Nice and Vibrant. Stayed right across Darling Harbor while in Sydney for 4 days.. Vibrant place with lots of options to grab a pint, or dine!! Was there during Australian day celebration.. Fantastic fireworks.. added more color to this place!!
fantastic setting. stayed at the Sheraton over looking darling harbour. The setting was just fantastic with great choice of bars and restaurants in such an idyllic setting. Well worth a visit

Lovely harbour with good restaurants!. Lovely harbour, nice restaurants/cafes - we visited Nicks seafood restaurant one night which was great, really good food. Plus there is Madame Tassauds and a wildlife place at one end of the harbour and you walk right down that end to catch the ferry onto Circular Quay.
Spend a day. We walked around, ate a very reasonably priced lunch and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. A must place to visit whilst in Sydney.

Good location. We went to Darling a Harbour to visit The Sea Life Centre and we weren't disappointed as it is very impressive. At the Harbour you can also visit The Zoo and Madam Tussaud's. Darling Harbour is very accessible either by foot or by Ferry as they run regularly.
Darling Harbour. Excellent bars and restaurants to sit and watch the world go by. They also had some excellent activities for the children to take part in.

Great place to visit. We had lunch in one of the restaurants along the walkway right on the water, sunny day and good food. Perfect day to do nothing in a great environment. We then strolled along the area listening to buskers and looking at the opera house and the huge P&O ship docked at the quay.

A must when in Sydney. We love Darling Habour and have been many times over the past 20 years. It is always so relaxing to wander, eat and stay at. The ferries go to Circular Quay (Opera House) on a regular basis but there is always things happening at Darling. Great dining over looking the water, museums, Aquarium, shopping - just perfect. Also good for families - the play ground is perfect for children of all ages, and the merry go around is simply devine.

Great atmosphere. Darling harbour always has something to see and do. It is well worth including a visit here while on holidays. Plenty of lovely restaurants, good views and activities for the family. Some good accommodation here as well.

awesome. if you like food ,wine,entertainment this is the place to be in Sydney..its known for its nice sea views and surround of high rise buildings and the buskers that admist in the region...a great day out.and a place where you have some chill time out a must for the overseas vistor....

Lots of options. Darling Harbour can be reached either by ferry or going through the city. We took the ferry. It is the up and coming area of Sydney. It has many bars and restuarants, and a Chinese Garden. It also opens up into the Chinatown area of the city. A pleasant way to spend part of the day.

What an amazing place to want around. The atmosphere of this area is truly amazing. I happened to be in Sydney and there were dragon boat races on all day on the Saturday. I wandered through the crowds, they were all chanting and cheering for their teams, I watched the races from the foreshore and from the bridge. Great area, and felt really safe walking around late at night too, when we walked from hotel to the casino. Well worth a vist.

Delicious Darling Harbour. We loved Darling Harbour, great mix of attractions, restaurants & boat trip/cruise options for all ages. Along with street entertainers, sculpture and most of all fun, we liked strolling around and stopping off at whatever took our fancy. We stayed at The Menzies Hotel(great - recommended) over the New Year period which was less than 10 mins walk away. During our 5 night stay ate at various restaurants on Darling Harbour always having a good meal, the city views at night were fantastic. Be aware Darling Harbour is big so if you have any walking difficulties or young children there is a little motor train you can take to have a look round. Darling Harbour was my favourite place in Sydney, make sure you go and spend sometime there to take in everything it has to offer.

Loved it....First Night impression of Sydney. After a long flight to Sydney, we walked from hotel a short distance to the harbor. So much activity on a Saturday night and walking along the harbor was such fun. We got to experience a wonderful fireworks show - something I understand they do every Saturday night. Lots of restaurants and bars available.

The best part of Sydney. Unending restaurants, great night clubs, great walk, great atmosphere & a must visit again & again. The star of sydney. avoid the show boat though ( especially for vegetarians )

Mixed bag. If you're looking for upmarket dining, this is the place. If you want a cheap eat - you better bring your own with you! A great place to people watch and often activities going on in the area which are good to get involved in or just kick back and watch.
Lovely. Plenty of restaurants to choose from and a good place to sit and relax.They have fireworks there on a new years eve but get there early

Needs the current work hurried up.. Few years since we took the time out to visit Darling Harbour socially, been to lots of trade Fairs etc., but we took the time out to have a good look around over the holiday.Sadly it all appears a bit rundown, I know theirs a lot of work going on to revamp areas of it but it seems to be full of cheap market stall shops, what happened to all those great name brands that and great galleries that used to be their? Its just a continuation of Paddy's Market in many respects.Hope they do something soon as it was a great location

Pretty with a lot to do. The zoo, aquarium, and maritime museum are all within a short walking distance of each other at Darling Harbour. Also there are a lot of great restaurants, pretty boats to look at, and the Olympic marker/sculpture. If you are planning to go to the museums mentioned previously then I would plan on spending a day in the area. Also, this is where we boarded our New Year's Eve cruise.
Place To Visit. Great place to walk around. Good choice of restaurants. We eat at Kazbah, which is Moroccan style restaurant. Wine is quite expensive but otherwise it was good.

Fantastic, plenty to see and do.. Darling Harbour is a wonderful place to spend the day when in Sydney, there are heaps of restaurants and a great shopping mall, the Maritime Museum is close by and very interesting and usually free except for special event showings. If you are looking for a place to stay while in Sydney book your accommodation close to this and you will have a more interesting stay.

The Maritime Museum is a must. Darling Harbour is a lovely place to walk around, lots to see and do, good food too. The Maritime Museum is excellent and well worth a visit if you like anything to do with the sea - or even if you don't, you can learn about early Sydney and how it came about.

Darling Harbour. Darling Harbour was very nice. There's the IMAX movie theater and a lot of things to see and places to go. Every Sunday there's these cool fire works and the whole place is completely packed. There's also the Hard Rock Café Sydney. :)
oh dear. the only disappointing part of our three day trip to Sydney. very very commercial with no heart or beauty

A Scenic Walk. You get a taste of everything when visiting the darling harbour. There are always activities going on, family outings and the option of relaxing close to the water. Close to attractions and restaurants. Something that anyone can enjoy.
Darling Harbour. Easily accessible by ferry system as well as hop on hop off bus (great deal which gives you 24 hours from when you buy your ticket.)

Beautiful especially at night.. This is such a lovely place. Lots of exciting things to do and lots of restaurant to eat at. I did quite a bit of the attractions on darling harbour. At night it is even more lovely as the lights reflect off the water. This is a great place and I will be returning.
Very family friendly. Definitely brings your family here, very beautiful and has many things for the whole family to do. Lots of restaurants nearby
Nice area. Watch fireworks on Saturday and a very nice waterfront view in the evening and have a beer at the waterfront

sunset, fireworks, perfect!. we were here in Jan and they had fireworks on selected days and lots of other activities like outdoor movies. great night out, caught a bit of the movie, sat on the pier and watched the sunset and the fireworks ended up being shot pretty much right in front of us. absolutely perfect night!
As always great place to eat. Had a few meals down here and enjoyed every one of them. Good good but not cheap, but the food was delicious and the service very good and the location is fabulous.

Great Spot. Fantastic spot for singles and families so much to see and do here. Maritime museum was good fun and you need a few hours here. Not so good for small children though. Loved the restaurants and bars here very family friendly just loved it and hope to visit again soon. We only wish WA will do something like this on our development of the river in the city.

Highly Tourist Area. Not my Cup of Tea. This newer area is highly tourist driven with many chain type restaurants and stores. New Hotels, etc. For some traveler's, this may be cool, but I like to visit a city and get the vibe and history feel. This provided neither

Very expensive evening. We went to Darling Harbour on a Saturday evening. There were a lot of stag and hen nights going on. Very entertaining. There is quite a lot to see and do, but mostly during the day. Most weekends they have entertainment going on and sometimes fireworks. The only place we could get something to eat was at a Pizza restaurant which was very expensive and not worth the money, otherwise we had a good evening.
A must visit in Sydney. Enjoyed the atmosphere in the day and night. There is a lot of eateries ranges from affordable to expensive which makes this place unique!

Lots to do and see. While it may not be as big as Sydney Harbour, this area is also beautiful. There are lots of places to eat, lots of attractions, and a water playground for the little ones. A great place to go for a walk and enjoy the scenery.
loved it. I have been here several times with friends, family and even with my husband. I love this place and will love to go there again and again when i get chance.

So much on offer here with the kids. Grab the kids and head down to the park at darling harbour. Make sure you pack the swimmers and towels as the water play there is exceptional. Loads of restaurants to choose from and you can catch a ferry back to circular quay.

Wonderfull setting. A great choice of restaurants and a food court for those wanting to spend a little less. Imax cinema also here. Great fireworks which are plentiful in December and good views from the bridge

Christmas Eve Fireworks at Darling Harbour. We with our eighteen months old son had been to Darling Harbor two times. First time, we took the ferry from Circular Quay and the second time walked from the Town Hall Train Station. On the Christmas eve, there was several events around the harbor side. Although, there was supposed to be Christmas Carole around the tree, but we were not able to find which place was mentioned as by the tree. Then again, we were happy to sit for almost two hours to keep seats near the water and we experienced Christmas eve fireworks at 9:00pm. I was a bit worried about my son watching his first fireworks, but he seemed to be captivated by the sound and light around him. It takes a lot of effort to keep our son sitting one place for longer than 5 seconds, but the fireworks did that for almost 15 minutes. So, it was a great time spent.
Nicely done!. Loved this place, went back several times to try different restaurants and attractions. its pretty easy to walk and theres a small shopping centre.

Very good area to visit. We were fortunate in that we got to see 2 firework display from darling harbour. We also saw a samba parade and event in and around the area. The food around here was great (but generally very expensive)

Great meeting point, place to hang out. Great meeting point and place to hang out with the kids. There's a visitors centre, tourist shop and lots of restaurants to choose from. There are also a couple of activities to keep the kids busy. We went to the park every time we went. My son loved the zip wire there. There was also a dinky train that travelled from one end of the harbour to the other which he loved.

Nice enough setting with various attractions. Such is the size of the harbour that there are two ferry stops in the area which can tie-in with a visit to a particular attraction - one at the Maritime Museum, the other at the Aquarium. It is also home to the Conference Centre, a casino, Madame Tussauds and Sydney Wildlife World.The whole area is encircled with eating establishments although we found many of them quite similar - it’s mostly casual dining on a large scale. If you tire of eating and the other attractions there is also some shopping behind the scenes in a large mall.There is plenty of open space and the area has some attractive landscaping so it’s nice enough to just stroll around enjoying the atmosphere and take a walk over the Pyramont Bridge which crosses the harbour. Not many places to sit, unless you’re comfortable on concrete stairs, etc - or happy to spend in the bars or restaurants.We had considered visiting the Maritime Museum however there was an entry fee of AUD$7 to the attractive looking building and this increased to AUD$25 if you wanted to include visits onboard some of the historic vessels moored in the harbour. We decided not to bother.The monorail was being dismantled when we were there and is presumably now gone.It’s a likely destination for anyone with children (for the attractions) and worth a trip on the ferry from Circular Quay to enjoy the city landscape from the water and a wander around.
Great place to chill out. My first experience was one of wow I wish we had a place like this back home. It is great for eating drinking or a family outing.

Lively place on a weekend. This is a beautiful place to stroll around day and night with fantastic views of the city etc. As our Hotel was only a short walk away we visited it on our first night where we were treat to a magnificent firework display. There is a selection of shops, dining options, Bands playing Australian Aborigines putting on dance shows and many more. We also spent a leisurely Sunday there meeting up with some relatives of mine from Wollongong, Canberra and Melbourne.Don't miss it especially on a weekend
Excellent place to visit in evening. What a lovely place this was. Felt like everyone was in a festive mood. The eating joints are great! So many options with lovely view of the harbour.

Crowd Control on Australia Day.. Australia Day in Darling Harbour this year was an appalling experience. Surely this event has been going on long enough for the organisers to be able to get crowds moving - albeit slowly - without having a crush which was traumatic for two older travellers, one quite elderly. For heavens sake - this city hosted an Olympics! I was held up in what was, admittedly, a *somewhat* good natured crowd for well over half and hour - stuck. The Shanghai Bund on China National Day has nothing on this - a city with a population of the whole of Australia. All it would have taken, as I could see it, would have been some control to allow people to move slowly in one direction or the other. - barriers, security people - making it clear which queue to join to move in which direction. And they really must ban strollers. Strollers make the chaos worse. Families should come, but be prepared to dismantle their strollers and carry their children. Or ... the authorities must work harder to control the crowds.But ... the fireworks were - it must be said - spectacular. Was the effort to come from interstate for this event alone justified? I would say no. Other cities in this country also put on excellent skyshows on Australia Day.Just as well we had other things planned for our trip to Sydney which made the trip a great success over all.
