There is so much to do, and everyone in Darling Harbour is friendly, helpful, and heaps of good food prices , brunch and evening available

Excellent place to hang out. Excellent place to hang out with resturants, shopping and nice places to set and relax. it is excellent for walking, you can also take the speed boat or taxi boat to anywhere
Best big breakfasts in town.. I love this place. Have stayed in the vicinity many times. Great access to transport. Awesome for big brekkies and great for lunch, dinner or just a few quiet ones.
Gorgeous at night. To be sitting in one of the restaurants overlooking the harbour in the evening feels wonderful. Beautiful picture opportunities.
Good.. The view is really nice and to walk along in the night is a good experience. Near the harbour there are many attractions and u can spend good time exploring the museum and wild life.

What's not to like?. When I went to Australia 20 years ago this area was just starting to be renovated. Now it is a buzzing, vibrant centre attracting tourists and locals in large numbers. We ate and drank here on several occasions and always had great nights, as we watched the world go by!

Great place to just hang out!. This has to be one place that you can keep visiting and never get bored. Great for kids, families or just going with friends for a coffee. Always something going on with entertainment and of course the harbour is beautiful .
Pier 39 Australian Style. Great public accommodations but very touristy (which may be just what one needs on occasion). Best feature was walk across Pyrmont Bridge.

Fireworks. We visited the harbour the night before the fire works for diner with friends and it was a buzzing atmosphere. It was really enjoyable.
The following night we returned and watched the firework show. (Saturday nights @ 8.30) It lasts about 10 to 15 min and if worth a watch great for the kids.
Recommend this to everyone.

Very Impressive. Sydney has done a marvelous job to revitalise Darling Harbour. From Tumbalong Park to the Maritime Museumand everything in between there is plenty to do over a period of 2/3 days without rushing, and all accessible by walking. You will find it very difficult to be disappointed. Especially good if you have kids.

We had dinner at this beautiful harbour. Our local Australian colleague took us for dinner in one of the restaurants in this beautiful & crowded famous harbour. The atmosphere was really good and the choices of food in the restaurants were also excellent.

Good Attractions for Young Kids. Darling Harbour is very touristy. There are lots of attractions for kids though. We rode the now defunct Monorail and visited the Sealife Aquarium which was good but very expensive.
Best place in Sydney. Darling Harbour was always my favorite place for a walk. They have fireworks on saturday, some good restaurants and a few places to party.

So much to do so much to see!. Bars, clubs, restaurants, shopping centres and so much nature! What more could you want! I spwnt three days there and it still was not enough! Make sure to check out harbourside shopping centre!

FANTASITC. Darling Harbour is beautiful, its a hub of resturants and cafes around a beautiful harbour. You can catch a ferry here from circular key and back late. Darling Harbour put on a fire works show which is well worth seeing every saturday night at 7.30 or 8pm check the web site for times but dont miss it. If you dont want to spend too much on food, go to the mall food court were you can get a budget meal.
Pretty. I love walking around the Harbour and looking at all the boats and eating at some of the restaurants. People all seem friendly and the weather was perfect.

Great for Sidney vibe!. We had limited time in Sidney and were advised to spend the day here. Easy getting ferry from downtown Marriott, but could easily walk in this area. Saw a Bollywood movie in production, ate at a great Brazilian restaurant and shipped for souvenirs at Patty's Market. Beautiful setting with fountains and gardens all though the area. People were so friendly and helpful. Can't wait to go back as we didn't get to explore Chinatown and some of the attractions. You won't be disappointed.
Don't miss Darling Harbour. Excellent restaurants & sights to visit. Such as the Maritime Museum, Aquarium, Submarine, Warship, etc...
Nice. It was a very nice harbor, and they had fireworks late on Saturday night when I was there. It's nice, and worth a trip! The ferry is a great way to get there.

Really nice. This area is great with plenty of little bars and places to eat. Gelatissmo down near the imax next to subway is lovely but just to be warned there scoops are giant and 1 scoop is plenty!

Excellent attraction. something for everyone, if you just want to sit and people watch, or eat at one of the many restaurants from budget to expensive. There is the aquarium excellent display of underwater life. Waxworks from early Australian to the latest movie and pop stars. Chinese gardens, maritime museum, Imax theater lots of stuff for kids and expensive shopping.Great atmosphere, you will need more than a day to see everything and you will need lots of $$$$

Live there. I used to live there, it's amazing.. every saturday there are fireworks like new year's eve! It's full of restaurant, pub, shopping center, imax(the cinema with the biggest screen in the world), the park.. Everything! The best time for go there it's during the Vivid for see the light show.

Best harbor in Sydney.. What a nice place even better than Sydney harbor on my second visit to Sydney I stayed close by and love to walk along the harbor in the early mornings, not as busy as Sydney but much much cleaner friendly and to me safer, Plenty of sitting ares paddling ares for kids and some nice coffee shops along the way. Also nice shopping areas great place and one of Sydney's highlights.

Lots to do. Shopping, the worlds largest IMAX, the Chinese and Japanese gardens, harbourside shopping, the aquarium, zoo, waxworks, maritime museum, the Ferries, and the Pyrmont Bridge. Add in many good restaurants and it's somewhere you'll probably visit more than a couple of times whilst in Sydney.
Absolute must visit. OK, all will see the harbour from the Hop on hop off bus.Take a ferry to appreciate the beach.Lots of local restaurants.We liked the 4 story cinema.Local flavourTake the ferry

A great way to spend the day. Darling Harbour offers many opportunities for visitors to Sydney. Numerous restaurants and attractions to see. When my husband and I visited we planned our days in different areas of Sydney. I can recommend the Maritime Museum for fascinating history and Madame Tussauds for a bit of light hearted fun.

Too Crowded. The Darling Harbour area is too commercialized and crowded. Not a place you can enjoy a stroll around. The good thing is it's well connected by the ferries and the monorail. I prefer Sydney Harbour to this place.

A nice day trip. I was lucky enough to catch the monorail to Darling harbour and whilst there watch many of the local street acts, most of which were amazing. This is not a must see part of Sydney but worth a look if there for a few days.

Just lovely. Lots of great little shops and nice restaurants
Best Saturday night book early to get a great seat for Fireworks

Very Nice. Very nice harbour. A great deal of places to eat and close to a shopping mall. Very convenient to stay near Darling Harbour because there is a lot going on there. We went in the winter, I can only imagine it is much more lively in the summer. Almost every Saturday has a fireworks show.

Darling Harbour on a weekend is a busy place. It is fantastic to see so many adults and children, both local and tourists, from so many ethnic and religious backgrounds enjoying the sun, street performers, play equipment, attractions, food etc, it has a fantastic atmosphere and really should not be missed.

Simply the Best. Sydney is a great city, Sydney Harbour is also great. But the best of all is Darling Harbour which also has a great ambience.
We went to the fireworks display on the Saturday night which although relatively short was a lovely experience in the night air and with a large gathering of spectators.

The best place to be in the heart of the city of Sydney. Darling Harbour is one of Sydney's CBD landmark. For free, absolutely, you will enjoy your day wandering around, enjoying your shopping,Lots and lots of restaurants, or if you prefer 5 star dining, there's a few just a few distance from each other, 5 Start Hotels, and also quality take away foods . Have lunch overlooking the waterfront .Just the view is spectacular, You can just walk from George St Queen Victoria Bldg, the Westfield shoppingtown, to Chinatown and even to Circular Quay. Its all walking distance. Wear comfortable shoes an attire, and don't forget your camera to capture great view of Darling Harbour. You will be impressed. Everything you could as for is here....

Food, tranquility and sea gulls. Wide array of Italian, Japanese, Chinese and other cuisines.The jetty and the harbour gave us a strong feeling of tranquility - bustling and alive, yet very unrushed, almost rhythmic pulse-beat as we watch the builidngs, people and the sea gulls and ibis flying or waddling around boldy. Good place to walk and take in the sights and the breeze.

Heart of the City and absolutely free!. Darling Harbour is one of Sydney CBD's treasures, so many different places to walk, talk and eat and so much going on. Very easy to spend half the day just walking around and of course that costs you nothing if you can resist the aroma of fine coffee, or walk past the gourmet icecream shops. Great restaurants - of course! Some are fine dining and naturally quite expensive, but if that sort of eating is not on your budget, there are so many alternatives. Many of the eateries have outside dining and display their menus out on the footpath, so very easy to choose. Various attractions for the kids, Tumbalong Park - often used for cultural and sporting events, the harbour itself with its water taxis, ferries, and other boating activities. I recommend this venue for Australia Day but get there early as it will be standing room only for the fireworks displays.
Nice. Good place to wander around. Lots of eateries and things to see and do. Some nice sculpture. A pleasant way to spend a few hours.

Well Worth the Walk. A stones throw from the bustle of the downtown core is this hive of activity. Situated on a horseshoe-shaped bay, this is a pleasant walk and a great spot to see the Sydney skyline from a completely different angle. It is a 15 minute walk from the heart of the city. The biggest movie screen in the southern hemisphere is found here too at the IMAX theatre. Many options are available for every craving of the food and beverage kind. From simple take-away gelato to towering seafood platters, it is all here! The National Maritime Museum is located at one end and it too is well worth a visit (entry fee). There are Naval vessels moored there, from antiquated replica tall ships to stealth submarines and the historical tour inside is fascinating. To cross from one side to the other by foot, the walker is treated to not only great views but also a short stroll, over one of the last operating 'pivot-bridges' in the country. The bridge periodically swivels to afford ships with tall masts entry to the refuge of this little harbour. The best value for food is found in the food-court inside the 2 level mini-mall located beside the convention centre entry doors. This is a great spot for lazy fish & chips, a high-end sit down dinner, a cold beer, a pleasant coffee or take in a movie. Great walk from the main hotels. Well worth the easy effort. There are countless shops to pick up everything from beautiful photographs to authentic Australian keepsakes. Highly recommend.

Worth visiting. This is one of the best areas in Sydney, plenty to see and do.. some fantastic restaurants with great atmosphere.Take your time when visiting as its worth the time to explore and enjoy all it has to offer.We go there every time we visit Sydney and have always totally enjoyed ourselves.

A tourist venue with some restaurants as good as anywhere in the wor. There are some very good restaurants in Darling Harbour & plenty of choices. Great on a nice sunny evening & you take a ferry from the CBD (Circular Quay) Wharf for a relaxing evening

Great place for families. We took in Darling Harbor as part of our Hop on Hop off ferry tour. Main objective was to go to The Maritime Museum. We got off the ferry at the Darling Harbor stop planning to walk around to the Maritime Museum and possible go into the Aquarium. It was a school holiday and we quickly learned that all of the museums and attractions would be very crowded. So we took the monorail around the periphery to see what that was all about then got off at The Maritime Museum. Spent the entire day there and wished we had started there earlier. It was the best museum we visited in Australia. From the ships outside to the exhibits inside, it was a 5 Star experience. Great for old and young. You need to be able to walk for the outside exhibits but many things handicapped accessible inside. DO NOT MISS THIS ATTRACTION!!! Darling Harbor is very touristy and great for families. I am sure there is great night life for young people. Easy access by ferries or busses or monorail.

still has a zip. Very worthwhile spending a bit of time wandering around the area. Try to hit it at food o'clock and preferably if you feel thirsty. Plenty of nosh and booze places with views of the water. Only a very short walk from the city leads to a pleasant afternoon.
Great location. Great place to get a bite to eat, take in museums and take in the Viva festival if travelling at the right time of year.

Such choice!. If you're hungry and want a no-miss place to go find food, this is the place. It seemed an entertainment centre with dozens of restaurants, and IMAX, HUGE park w/ water features and playground for kids, convention centre...this area had it all!

A great place visit in Sydney. I visited Sydney along with my family for family holiday. We stayed in a hotel at Darling Harbour. The Vivid Sydney Festival started on the day we arrived. This is a fortnight long festival show casing some of the best spots in CBD like Harbour Bridge, Opera House, Darling Harbour coming alive with beautiful lights, laser shows and projection videos. Darling Harbour has a lot to offer to visitors. It has a wide range of restaurants, shops, an IMax theatre, a Chinese Garden and a market (Paddy's Market) which sales a range of stuff at very cheap price. We enjoyed aquatic shows (light, music, laser and water display) every evening. The firework every night was spectacular. As it has a number of transport options including monorail and ferries going to other places is very easy. I recommend every visitor to Sydney to spend at least a day at this happening place.
Great experience. It was very fun to visit this place. Many restaurants, shops and entertainment around. You could spend the whole day there

waterfeatures. A great place when you have kids with you. Many waterfeatures where the kids can play on a hot summers day. Plenty of room for many tourists. Close to the harbour,with many restaurants.

Burstling Harbour. So many things to do and so many things to see... where to start and where to end... I love the relaxing walk around ..window shopping... yummy food at the cafes.... oh..too many to list... just explore..

Excellent place. Nice place, really cool.
Best part is the ongoing vivid show which even features aquamatic vivid shows (light displays on water fountains).
On few Saturdays this aquamatic vivid is accompanied with fireworks show too.
A must watch...
Free fireworks on Saturday night!. The best part was definitely the free fireworks! Absolutely beautiful. Grab some dessert and watch the fireworks at 8.30pm.
Always something going on to see and do. The walk along the waterfront to Circular quay and the mixture of shops, restaurants and entertainment makes Darling Harbour a must to visit.

Nice place to visit. As we had decided to stay near the Central Station, Darling Harbour was just a few minutes walk away. In fact it was the first place we visited having arrived earlyish after flying in from Hong Kong. We wanted to go for a quiet stroll to get us into the Sydney atmosphere and this made an ideal start to our visit. It was a lovely sunny morning, great for a stroll, and we even got to go on the soon to be dismantled monorail. During our time in Sydney we went back to visit the aquarium and also to go for an evening meal with relatives when we got to see it all lit up. Nice to see all the families walking around enjoying themselves in what looked to be a clean and safe family environment. Well worth spending some time there.

Cruises and more. Darling harbour is the place for fun , day or night.. cruises, lunches and dinners, Nicos Cafe a fun Italian place.. when you go the Musuem of tassauds fun too.. So much to do there...A must for overey visitor or local for Sydney

Catch the fireworks Sat night while dining here!. During the day, visit the aquarium and maritime museum. On Saturday night, dine along the harbour and catch the fireworks afterwards 830PM. Italian cuisine was excellent at Baia Restaurant.

Lots to see and do. Darling Harbour has something for everyone. Restaurants (look for drink and food specials), museums, attractions (Aquarium, Madame Tussauds, Wildlife Sydney. Great place to people watch. Be sure to walk over the Pyrmont Bridge.Short stroll to Chinatown and Paddy's Markets. Spend a few hours or all day.
Day and Nightlife. So much to do and see from the maritime museum to the numerous bars and restaurants on either side of the harbour.
Worth a visit. If you're staying in Sydney, you should go for a stroll to Darling Harbour. There are plenty of good eating options there, as well as Adiano Zumbos Macaroon shop which is awesome.
A bit too touristy, but worth a little visit. The restaurants are all too touristy for me, it's not cool like Bondi is, but still it's not too bad.

Very touristy. I'm always drawn to Darling Harbour as it's a great resting and eating place full of a stunning array of restaurants. Heaps of seating around the waters edge, play areas for kids not far away. Short walk to Chinese Garden and Hay Market and the Maritime Museum. Crowded but easy to find your own vantage point to rest.

Picturesque. A sunny afternoon in Darling Harbour and the pavement cafes are crammed with all nationalities enjoying the area. Shops, a maritime museum, mini tour train, boats or just sit back and enjoy the view. The ferry runs to and from Circular Quay or you might take the monorail into the city. Night time and the bars and hotel lights glitter on the water and you can be assured you are in the most happening part of Sydney!
A great spot. Darling Harbour s a great spot for ll, day or. Ignt. There is a great play area for ksd, fantastic restaurant, grea for a walk, some shops, hotels, IMAX ....

Nice place. The Darling Harbor is a great place to visit, they have a large variety of excellent restaurants, shops, neat fountains, and the Chinese Garden is close by. It is pretty during the day, but I recommend going at dusk, when there are great happy hour prices for cocktails, the sun is setting over the horizon, and the lights of the city come on. It is magical.

Just a great atmosphere. The restaurants along side darling harbour just makes for a fantastic atmosphere. It really comes alive at night.The only complaint I would give is that the restaurants are a little pricey. I remember being charged $4.50 for sauce on my steak!I guess you kind of expect this in darling harbour.Highly recommended. Would definitely go back again.

Great Location - Darling Harbour. We walked around the Darling Harbour area several times during our recent trip to Sydney, went both at night and during the day, very vibrant area of Sydney, great choice of places to eat, even on the Saturday night we were there had the added bonus of a fireworks display. Also very large kids playground in Darling Quarter that our 4 year old loved, water features playground items are great especially on a hot day.

Fun visit to Maritime Museum. The harbor is easily reached from Sydney and features restaurants and especially the Maritime Museum. This well done. We especially liked the visit to a replica of the ship sailed by Captain Cook. Guides on board explained how the ship worked and made the visit very interesting. The exhibits were well displayed and we stayed much longer than expected due to the quality of th eexhibits.

Another must see. You must visit this harbour too, very pleasant, great views and attractions. Specially the maritime museum. The aquarium or zoo don't look like much and are overpriced. To reach here, Take the ferry from the circular Quay for some great views along the way.

A beautiful harbor and view. We walked over the bridge to get there from staying in Central downtown. A beautiful view. Lots of shops, restaurants, a great park to bring children too and all within walking distance. We went early in day just to see it and went back for dinner as it was so nice. Would highly recommend.

Once is more than enough.... The harbour itself is reasonably OK to walk around with minimal photo opportunities, and there are some attractions like the Aquarium and Tussauds that will keep your interest for a while. The restaurants however whilst providing good views over the harbour are uninspiring and over priced. We had identified a number potentially to visit but on inspection left us totally underwhelmed. The Saturday night fireworks may be a reason to go then and pay the price. The IMAX at the time had absolutely nothing on that would attract. We spent 2 hours there and most of that was looking round the retail shops. Been there, done that will not be going back!!

sweet harbour. the name means every thing!!! darling harbour!! it is a real darling! so many nice restaurants there as well as many things happening, shopping, eating, play ground, shows, everything happening, its the place to be, if you go to Australia, this is A place you must go!!!

Bit pricey and noisy. Whilst it is a must just to say you have been, the prices on the waterfront strip are really way over the top and you can eat for less in better surroundings at plenty of places less than ten minutes away, nothing that flash about the businesses here.

Great Place to wander. Darling Harbour has a diverse number of attractions and is a great place to centre your trip to Sydney.Lots of restaurant options and activities.Very pleasant to just sit and observe and soak up the atmosphere.

Festival Atmosphere. The place is a delight for photographers. Lots of people and lots of eating places, and, everybody seems to be enjoying. There are several places of interest here like the aquarium, zoo and the recently added Madame Tussaud's wax Museum.

Good spot to visit but a one-off. Positives:Close in the city so easy to get to, selection of restaurants, activities incl sydney aquarium, ferries, a submarine tour, tall ship tour, Chinese gardens, Chinatown and a tired old monorail (soon to go).Negatives:Prices, not safe after dark, some attractions are boring and tired... iMac cinema is terribleFrom a 30 something professional couple who both live/work in Sydney (we're both local legal practitioners). I'm proud of Australia as a whole, HOWEVER.... When recommending the place to overseas family, I tell them to only stay maybe two days in Sydney and move on.... Tick Opera House and bridge off the list but skip the Bridge Walk... It's wayyyyyyyy too over-priced and targeting the well-heeled Asian tourists who seem to splurge on everything.... (Currently in London and toured the London Shard & The Eye which are similar and prices are way more on the money).... Try having dinner instead at the revolving restaurant at Centre-point tower.... Kings Cross is just as seedy as thirty years ago, Bondi is just a beach after all and not a great one at that.... Much much better up and down the coast..... ESP the north and south coasts....We travel yearly to the UK, Europe, Canada and Pacific regions so comparisons are made with tremendous amount of OS experience ...All in all, Darling Harb is a two hour visit (including a quick meal) at best and that's it..... Move on....

Nice Area. This area is one of the nicer ones in the core area of Sydney to stroll or hang out. There are several nice restaurants in the area as well as some worthwhile shops. But the major attraction is the scenery. It is an excellent place to appreciate the waterscape and to snap a few good photos.

Tourist Center. Darling harbour is like the tourist hub of Sydney. It does have alot to offer catering for all ages. From fancy restaurants , simple eating and holds the centre of alot of tourist attractions. For our family it tends to attract us as it is an easy day out to entertain the kids!

Nice view, shame about the restaurants. Darling harbour is interesting to walk around, however the restaurants in the area seem to trade off the location and not much else. Uninspiring, over priced, average service seems to be the norm. If you're looking for Sydney's tourist traps - then Darling Harbour is one of them. Not really much reason to return.

Darling Harbor is a great place to hang out in the evening. Darling Harbor is great in the evening. Tones of Restaurants to choose from and hip area. Be wary - this is a touristy area so prices are slightly inflated. Also, many places have a surcharge if you eat on Sunday.When I was there, they were doing Fireworks every Saturday at 8:30PM. Not sure if this is seasonal or not.The Circular Quay ferry gets you here in about 30-45 minutes (because of other stops, it would be faster to walk from Circular Quay), but is an enjoyable ride that takes you under the Sydney Harbour bridge and brings you close to Luna Park. Very good for night ride. Be wary the last Ferry typically leaves between 10-10:30PM so plan accordingly. There are many taxis, and it is still a short enough walk from everything (including Wynard Station - about 10 minutes).Attractions in the area include Madame Tussauds, Aquarium, and Zoo (all owned by same company).Darling Harbour also hosts the worlds largest IMAX. Just be prepared to spend over $20 per ticket (I spent about $31 for a 3D showing).
Lots to do here.. The Wildlife Zoo, Aquarium and maritime museum are all located here. Easy to get here from the ferries.

Saturday night fireworks Oooooh AAaah!. Fireworks were great (and free) and there are lots of food places around for a late night dinner after this. Is a real tourist hub with lots of places to drink and eat. Will be going back for drinks/fireworks/food this Saturday!

Great views. The harbor had very good views from both the monorail and walking bridge. I do not like all the shops seemed to be a tourist trap for shopping. The Hard Rock Café is here. The ride on the monorail is a great ride over to experience Chinatown.

Very Enjoyable. Well worth the visit for any tourist, plenty of restaurants to have lunch and a drink by the water. Usually there are some street entertainers around the area which are entertaining. A lot of sites to be seen around there and also some shopping for various things. Easily spend a day there.
Busy Day. We loved the wax people and the reptile park and the aquarium. Very busy day, but lots of interesting facts were learned along the way.

A little bit of everything. Has so much to offer - tourist attractions (Sydney Aquarium, Madame Tussauds, Maritime Museum, IMAX) and so much more. Restaurants of so many varieties you would never starve. Great play area for the kids, nice quiet little nooks for relaxing.

Seems a touristy and a bit corporate. We stopped at DH as part of a bicycle tour of Sydney with Bonza bikes. It was the only part of Syndey we didn't much care for. It seemed overly commercialised with a lot of global corporate names, which make it feel like you could be anywhere. There are better places to go in Sydney - lots of them.

Expected More. Liked the Harbour as it was busy but after reading all the guide books I was expecting it to be so much more, some building work being carried out at the far end of the Harbour. Plenty of restaurants offering a good choice of food at a price, cruise trips available to several tourist attractions,

Great atmosphere. Great place to visit. Saw a movie on the Imax, went to King Street Wharf for a great lunch, photographed seagulls. Everything is so close to Darling Harbour, walking distance, great exercise.
DON'T MISS DARLING HARBOUR. Lots here to satisfy every taste by way of entertainment, eating, and culture. Highbrow or lowbrow you'll find something here to occupy you, daytime and evening.

In a World of its Own. This little harbor was very quaint. Lots of little restaurants to grab a snack and/or brew. Get off at the Darling Harbor and then walk to the Maritime Museum over the bridge. The museum is interesting with an old WW1 cruiser and sailing ships to browse and at the end catch the ferry back to where you came.
Lots of Restaurant Choices. Nice area for an evening stroll along the water and to get dinner. With endless options for food, you won't go hungry. Many street musicians perform along the promenade

Plenty to do, eat and see. There is much to do at Darling Harbour - we indulged in some eating and drinking, some sight seeing around Cockle Bay, visited the Sydney Aquarium and Wildlife Sydney Zoo as well as the Australian Maritime Museum exhibits. Spent the best part of a day here and still did not see it all.
Worth a visit. Plenty of restaurants and bars with many offering "happy hours" between 3 and 7pm! Alcohol can be pricey and some restaurants offer $10 steaks.
Stay on Darling Harbour.. We enjoyed the restaurants along the water front. It is a great place to visit. Our favorite eating place was the The meat and wine Restaurant

Fun, fun, fun!. I only went there as a pilgrimage to the Hard Rock Café and boy was I surprised. The place is bustling with life. Live entertainment out in the open air (free), a circus, in inverted fountain for children of all ages to play in, an Imax theater, the Hard Rock Café.... What a nice place to spend the afternoon or maybe a whole day if what you want to do is relax, have fun, people watch....

Enjoy a glass of wine or cup of coffee and watch the world go by.. This is another great spot for tourists and Sydney locals alike. Darling Harbour has a range of interesting shops, great restaurants and a lovely boardwalk. Visit the Maritime Museum and the Welcome Wall which has names of emigrants, old and new, who made a new life in Australia. A seafood meal with a glass of good Aussie white wine while watching the world go by is a very pleasant way to spend some time out in Sydney.

Lots of eating options and nice for people watching. Darling harbour is a must see in Sydney. I would recommend grabing a drink or bite to eat at one of the outside restaurants and watching the boats and people go by.

Plenty To Do. Darling Harbour is full of things to do. Huge play area for kids, plenty of shopping and eating choices. Martime Museum, Aquarium, Wild Life Sanctuary and Madame Tussauds. The Chinese Gardens are definetly worth a look.

Peaceful, beautiful.... Think of a peaceful and beatiful place... this place is Darling Harbour. With plenty of restaurants and cafes, it's perfect for a delightful afternoon with friends/family. There are lots of buskers (very good ones, because to play in this place you need an approval from the government).

A Beautiful Place To Visit. My wife and I spent a day in the Harbour; first with a morning coffee cruise and then the balance of the day in the Harbour area just people watching and sipping a good glass of wine. On an impulse, we decided to see if we could get reservations for a tour of the Opera House on the following day. Turns out they had a tour leaving in five minutes and could accomodate us then. We took the tour and returned to sit and people watch. Beautiful downtown skyline, great views of the Harbour ferries and the Ocean Liner wharf. The Celebrity Solstice was tied up there on that day and we had disembarked in Sydney at the same place two weeks earlier from the Ocean Princess! All in all, a beautiful place to sit and watch things go by or join in the action!
Lovely in the sunshine. beautiful walk to the chinese garden, the maritime museum was really informative and we had chocolate and churros in the shopping complex.

Never Forget. Darling Harbour is very nice place of Australia.I saw lovely boats,colorful lights,yummy restaurants,smiling faces from tourist.I like fresh air and cool breeze across the habour when I walk around.

A cool place to visit - bring the family. Darling Harbor used to be an aging and ominous district of wharves and warehouses, where no tourist ventured unless they were lost. A little like Bonfire of the Vanities. But then they developed it in a masterful way. Now everyone goes to visit the entertainment, and the bevy of stores and restaurants for all tastes. Though it's "touristy", it is not all overpriced. Entertainment and great views of the cityscape and the harbour. The Maritime Museum is here. The nearby Paddys Market is where you can buy your inexpensive T-shirts and other souvenirs.

Too many Tourists. If you want to see the real Sydney then stay away from here. Take any other ferry and walk to a little junction or catch a bus which will meet the ferry at every other stop. Have a real meal at Mosman junction or Balmain

Incredibly Picturesque. Darling Harbour is a fantastic place, anytime of the day. Its easy to get to by public transport and offers some brilliant places to eat and drink at a sensible price.Quite a backdrop to accompany a nice meal.Highly recommended.

Part of the Sydney Experience, I guess.. Yeah, touristy and busy...but we hear some of the best restaurants in town are here. Walk through by day just to check out the scene. But ever better at night when the lights of the city are reflected in the water. It felt a bit too commercial and Disneyesque, but I suppose it's a great area if you have young kids. There were other areas of Sydney we preferred to spend time in, though. Guess you have to see it, but don't make this your only Sydney experience.

The Heart of Sydney. We were in Sydney for four days and nights; visiting Darling Harbour at least once every day was a compulsion. I will happily do the same on my next visit.Pradeep Thatai, London, England

An area with a feel of both Boston and San Diego all in one. This is my favorite part of the city and I stay here for a weekend each time I visit. You can walk anywhere and everywhere from here. There is always way to much to see and do, but I have never been disappointed. The views are incredible, and the restaurants are always varied and cover all the tastes. There is plenty of shopping, museums and ferry service to all other points. Dont miss Paddys market, if you are close to the weekend, which is walking distance from anywhere around this harbour. The only place I stay when I visit Sydney.
Tons to do for the Family!. Took the Ferry over from Circular Quay - bit rocky. But, getting to explore the Wax Museum, Aquarium & Wildlife Park was totally worth while. Fun day for the Family!

Harbour of pleasure. Went on a Sunday, busy and enjoyable. If you have the time go to the Maritime Museum, great experience fun for all ages. After that you have the shops, if you want and then the really hard decision, which of the 100s of great restaurants and bars do you got and sit, relax and chat at! I was lucky someone else made that decision for me
Great location. A wonderful choice of eating paces to suit all budgets. The fireworks on Saturday night in summer were an added bonus. Great ferry links around the harbour and beyond.

Great Spot!. Always plenty to see and do. When i'm in Sydney we always stay somewhere nearby Darling Harbour as they have a fantastic selection of restaurants and bars and plenty for the kids to do and see.
April festival. April a Great time to spend in Darling Harbour. Fireworks on Saturday nights. Place buzzing and lots of great restaurants. Maritime museum nearby. Central location. Loved it!
Peaceful and charming. This location was just a very nice place. There are shops, restaurants, cafes, IMAX,...It is the BEST location for the Australia Day firework!!!

Vibrant and picturesque. A great place to sit and watch boats and people come and go. The Sealife aquarium was worth the visit and there is a huge choice of cafes and restaurants along the quayside. We went to the Cargo Bar for the $10 steak - excellent value for money!

Happening at night. Lots of shops closes at night, but at darling harbour, the wide range of activities and restaurants that are still open in the evening certainly provide an alternative to spend your night. besides that ya can just hop on to the cruises.
Pretty place. Shops, restaurants, maritime museum and expositions, all on the waterfront. Nicely appointed and highly visited.
The great things here is the festivals..... I saw the Hoopla festival, and went back the next day, to the Hoopla Festival. What a great opportunity for free family fun in a lovely scenic area.

Lots to see, eat and do. I take visitors to Sydney here - amongst others. The food varied across many eateries and the water views and prominade are lovely on a sunny day. There's also the attractions of the aquarium and zoo for the youger ones and the IMAX cinema which I love.

Great place to spend evenings.. Many tourist attactions near by like sealife sydney aquarium,Madamme Tussauds,wild life sydney zoo and maritime museum.You stroll along the water front and there s.is blue fish restaurant and many more.Take a ferry from circular quay,takes about 10-15 mt

Great place.. This is a great place, plenty of restaurants and cafes, great open areas and fantastic views of the city and water. There is a great atmosphere to the place, it has a cool kids playground and is only about 10 minutes walk from the city centre. Chinatown with all its restaurants is also close by.

simply THE place to go with kids. You just have to go there and take supplies for all day because there's that much for them to enjoy and without spending a cent. The playground and water park will amuse them for hours its the absolute best place to be on a on a hot day. We did do the aquarium too and it is worth every cent but even so the other stuff is just as great.
So much to do.... Loved Darling Harbour! So much to see and do for people of all ages! Even just people watching is enjoyable.So easy to access too.

Loved Darling harbour. Our hotel was located 5 minutes from Darling harbour. We walked to the harbour every night for happy hour and sometimes diner as well. Yes it's touristy but so lively and fun! Great vibe, fun to people watch, great kid's park which was awesome (wish i was a kid again). We tried different places every night we went and enjoyed them all. It was a beautiful place with great views of the harbour pretty much everwhere you went. Would definately stay in this area again ! Oh and the souvenir shops were some of the cheapest (price wise) we saw. Same articles elsewhere in the city were much pricier, Paddy's market excluded as we didn't get a chance to go....

Beautiful, especially at night. I went to Darling Harbour with my Girlfriend as a weekend away. We stayed in a hotel over looking the Harbour. At night time the water looked beautiful as the lights were reflecting on the surface.The shopping arcade had a wide variety of shops to suit anyone and many hours could be spent here. There were many restaurants to choose from and lots to see and do. A beautiful area.

Enjoyable, lots of good shopping.. An enjoyable experience overall, this shopping arcade has had a breath of life again over the past few years, but the outside still looks decrepit. Good selection of shops and eating venues, mainly chains though. Its good for a visit when you're in the area, but wouldn't come here specifically for it.
Lovely area. Our hotel was in Darling Harbour so we walked through here several times. Great place to people watch. Lots of activities, Aquarium, Maritime Museum and many restaurants.

Tourist Heaven. I loved Darling Harbour - lots to see and do - lots of places to visit and be entertained and nice restaurants around here. It's great in the day but amazing by night with everywhere all lit up it is very special!

Very pleasant - but too many car flyovers. lots of restaurants, cinemas and the water. fireworks display on Saturday etc - but I just cannot get away from the road fly-overs that seem to dominate the area.

Not to be missed. We walked this area during the day and could not believe the variety of resturants along the harbour, seeing the different boats in the harbour was nice. But to see this area in the night with the lights on and people just chilling was something to remember.
Lovely views of harbour. Great place to sit and not views of Sydney, lovely boardwalk and great selection of cafes and coffee shops. Take the ferry out and get the full harbour experience.

A good example of city planning and a great tourist attraction!. Many cities can learn from the layout and facilities offered @ Darling Harbour, one of the many great spots in Sydney. There is something to do and see for absolutely anyone, it caters for all budgets, it is clean, safe, spacious and has fantastic views... what else you need? In saying that I was a bit dissapointed with the food court located at the Harbour Side Complex, some of the food on display from the various vendors looked old and the cleanliness wasnt' up to standards when we visited back in Mar 13.

Everything in one lovely place. Darling Harbour is a wonderful place to stay in Sydney. Most of the attractions are right on your doorstep or a quick walk or ferry away. The harbour looks wonderful. We stayed at the Four Points, and looked right over the harbour, wonderful views most days.There are also plenty of restaurants and cafes right on the doorstep too.

Awesome place. What isnt good about Darling Harbour. The view, the food, the atmosphere it is all in all a package deal. You can walk around there for hours just checking out places to eat or have a nice cocktail. It is also a good place for family too, lots of stuff for them to do including a park section to play in. Great for couples to enjoy time together!

We should have stayed here!. We first visited Darling Harbour at night, and it was a party. Lights on the boats, fireworks...what a place! There is everything here from Madame Tussaud's to a movie theater, from Margaritaville and the Hard Rock to local restaurants with the freshest fish. Darling Harbour is fun, lots to do and many places to eat and drink!

Must DO!!. Probably Sydney Opera House and the likes over shadow any other attraction - but the Darling Harbour is a must do ! With restaurants to food courts , to cafes to chilling around the harbour with great views - it has it all a must do for all ages.

Darling Harbour. We enjoyed our visit to Darling Harbour at Easter 2013.A geat choice of eateries, winebars and stores to keep our family engaged all day. The water views were magnificent with many boats moored in the harbour. We took a ferry journey to Manly,a very easy way to travel around the harbour.

Loved it!. We loved our time in Darling Harbour. There is a great playground for the kids, lots to see and do and tons of restaurants. One hint: after about 6pm there is not a lot going on in the downtown area of Sydney so head to the harbour to eat and see some entertainment. Great for the whole family.

All there for the whole family. From the aquarium to Madam Toussauds to the shops and restaurants. It is all great. Caught the ferry from Circular Quay. Great way to get there going under the Harbour Bridge. Fireworks at night just made it even better.
A sea of colour and activity. Darling harbour is great place to be at night - good restaurants and great views and always somethign happening
Nice Evening Out. It is a must see if your visiting Sydney. But for me its very touristy, just rammed but it does have a buzz about it! It has some really nice restraunts and bars!

Great place for families.. the best place in sydney is darling harbour, heaps to do and tonnes of places to grab a meal. Its especially good if you have young children as there is an amazing outdoor play ground.
Great place. What a lovely area to walk and browse, historic area, and great place to eat. Also in the harbour the maritime museum, wildlife & aquarium also highly recommended

Darling Harbour Great for Resturants. Some of the Harbours best Resturants are found in Darling Harbour. Lots of Quay side dining as well as upstairs resturants in the main shopping plaza. Easy ferry ride from Circular Quay or if the weather is nice it is not a long walk from the major hotels i.e., Marriot etc.

Darling area? Yes, definitely.. This tourist area is good to visit whether by day or night. Plenty to do and eat or drink.
The nearby Chinatown is quite magical in the early evening and well worth the short walk from the bright lights around the harbour. Eat here and fully enjoy the atmosphere.
Shame the monorail's day are numbered.
Amazing! Day and Night!. Day and night, this place is awesome! Bars, restaurants, chocolate shops, casino... and just plain BEAUTIFUL!

Enjoy your time on the water and go to Darling Harbor. Darling Harbor is a nice ride from the Zoo and a trip to the Sydney Aquarium, check out when they will have some shows with the animals, feeding etc. The underwater section was most interesting to see the ocean fish swimming over head, you might have second thought of just jumping in and going swimming, there are some big fish in there.

Great place for a family. Spend a couple of days at Darling Harbour on a recent visit to Sydney, really enjoyed it both days. A lot going if you are people watchers like us you would never get bored. Prices for food and drink were reasonable given the competition this would be expected. Understood why there were a lot of family groups especially on Sunday when it costs you $2.50 for unlimited use of public transport, hop off and hop on type.

Interesting but a bit spread out. There are a lot of attractions around here but they seemed a bit spread out - perhaps if we weren't trying to see too much in a day and made this our main focus it would have been easier. Would still recommend it, and perhaps using the monorail for access depending where in Sydney you are located.

Touristy Darling Harbour. It looks like any waterside development you've seen in the U.S.: Hard Rock Cafe, pricey seafood, etc. We thought the pizza might be affordable, but at $26 for a 12" personal pizza, we walked off and got a sandwich at Subway.

Super. Love Darling Harbour.great restaurants near the ferry terminus.Nick,s was our favourite with happy hour 3to 6 pm.Budget lunch $13 and wine$5 a glass.Lots of attractions sea life aquarium and wild life zoo.Walk further around the harbour through children's playing area to the Chinese Gardens.Wonderful.

Very "touristy" but still a nice walk. Combine it with shopping in the harbour mall. In case you want souvenirs, is probably even better to buy them there than at the souvenir shops. You don't even need to go to Bondi beach for a souvenir, you can all buy it there. Some nice bars and restaurants are there, too. Also good for a walk with kids.

Loud!. We went here for the Saturday night free fireworks, which were duly spectacular. But the harbour is then surrounded with expensive restaurants all playing very loud music - we had to leave to find modest food and drink for refreshment.

Very nice. Not to be missed when in Sydney, lots to see and do, weather permitting. A big shopping centre, lots of restaurants, a submarine to explore and also a water taxi to view the harbour bridge and many more things to do. The small train is a good way to see the sights at a reasonable cost.

Much improved facilities. We last visited Darling Harbour 12 months ago and on our return visit were very pleasantly surprised to see that there have been several new "attractions" incliding a water park for young children with lots of water features to play in which are all child friendly.The gardens have also been landscaped and make for a very pleasant walk through to the shopping areas.
Waterfront walkway. Good to walk in the afternoon or after dinner for drinks. It's water front walkway and there are many cafe and restaurant along. You can see the Sydney skyscraper and skyline.
Gorgeous. What a lovely way to spend an afternoon. Lots to see and do in beautiful surroundings. You were spoilt for choice in restaurants, shops and other activities.
Great Place. great places to eat and drink, gets quite busy at night so if you see a restaurant you want to eat in i would recommend to book a table.

Great Atmosphere. Great Atmosphere, choice of restaurants, shops, entertainment, bars and clubs. Harbourside has a massive range of specialty shops, while for entertainment you have many options, such as a stroll down to The Star Casino or going to the Imax theatre or the aquarium, many more things to do.

We could not get enough of this place on the last trip here. This is a beautiful area, surrounded by the Imax Theatre, the Convention Centre, and superb restaurants, gelaterias, and fantastic cafes. It is easily accessible from Chinatown, or via a bridge at the end of Druitt Street in the City. It is abuzz and ablaze with activity at all times of the day and night.
This is a fantastic place. Absoluely beautiful! Worth dining at the countless restaurants overlooking the Harbour. You would never want to leave!
tumblelong water park. this is great free entertainment for kids, so take a swimming costume because they cant help getting wet. loads of fountains, climbing rocks, canals to damn etc.

A fun and reasonably priced place to hang out. Darling Harbor is a great family environment. There are museums, play structures and the Chinese garden to make it very fun for the kids and adults. Catch a ferry from Circular quay. It's a fun trip that stops at Luns park and a couple of other points and makes for a scenic ride.

Beautiful Harbour. I have travelled extensively and I would have to say that Sydney Harbour is the best in the world. There are great restaurants and food halls with a varied of prices. You can walk across the walkway bridge, go to the imax, the gardens the exhibition Centre, Casino, night life, China town and close to the centre of Sydney. A must see.

Clean, lots of people. We went for a walk twice from hotel down to Darling Harbour and it was presented very cleanly - excpet for McDonalds which their outdoor seating area was very dirty. There were LOTS of people around due to the long weekend. Was very satisfied with all of the restrurants being open the whole Easter long weekend!
If you love crowds here's the place to visit. If you love crowds then Darling Harbour's for you. Lots of shops and restaurants and cafes. Overly busy park areas and buskers.

Tourist trap.... One of my least favourite places in Sydney. Unless you really want load of shops and opportunities to purchase tourist stuff, avoid it other than for a quick look. Plenty of other things to do in Sydney.Hint: the monorail ceases operation in June so if you want to have a ride on that, better rush.

Fabulous Easter Entertainment. Our arrival to Darling Harbour on Easter Sunday was like walking into a great big circus, with acts everywhere you looked. We were lucky enough to catch an act by The Dangles. These 3 amazing woman look and sound like they stepped out of the eighties. Two of them even looked similar to Kath and Kim. What they could do with big and small hoops was amazing. The Trapeze act was both brilliant and scary for those watching and the balancing act of chairs and glass bottles unbelievable. We are so lucky to have some amazingly talented people in this City let alone Country. The Dangles have a website we have been told, and if given the chance go and catch them in action just as we hope to do sometime soon.
Lots of tourist atmosphere and lots to see. A place to people watch some good bars - and some bad - most places have a happy hour between 5pm and 6pm so load up!

Go for Brunch. Lovely spot to head to for brunch. Take a lazy walk around the waterfront, maybe go and have a look in the submarine, or go to the Fish markets. Can't beat this for a lovely lazy brunch!

The Heart of Sydney Tourism. Spend the day at Darling Harbour. There are dozens of eateries ranging from cheap and cheerful to fine dining. Plenty of places to visit such as the Casino or Aquarium. A nice walk from Sydney Harbour

It's nice, definitely worth a visit. Having said that once you've been there's nothing to go back for. The fireworks over the weekend are good to see and there are always street artists around. It's nice to wander around on a Saturday, maybe catch a movie and grab some food. I think they could do more with the area though.
Darling Harbour. Buzzing location,close to city shopping and Casino. Access to Mono Rail,Light Railway and ferries an advantage.

Centre of it all. There is so much to do at Darling Harbour and with all the development plans, it will keep getting better. You can do the cheap thing with Macca's there, take the kids to play in the playground, or you can go up market with all the numerous restaurants available. The museum is great, watching the ferries is fun, and just chilling whilst appreciating a great city is priceless. There is an effort made each 'season' to give this place a happening vibe, and it works. I love the father Christmasses climbing all over the buildings in Dec!!

Restaurants, lovely cityscape and brilliant people watching!. What a fun area to have a wander, a meal and even watch some fireworks. There are lots of tourists but it feels completely "local" and everyone seems genuinely happy to see you.

A Darling of a harbor, but not the Soul of Sydney. We can appreciate how a lot of people like Darling Harbour, but we found it to be commercial and glitzy, and not representative of the soul of Sydney. That being said, it is a good place to take the kids as there is a lot to see with plenty of eye candy. If you are on a budget, you can take the free city bus from downtown a few blocks from Circular Quay, and get off near Darling Harbour. Once there you can walk along the water, take in the many sights, and have lunch at one of the many good restaurants. After lunch we walked back to Circular Quay along the water and through The Rocks, which is a great 2-3 mile walk.

Farewell to the Monorail. There is so much to do at Darling Harbour and it is a beautiful place to relax and eat at the many restaurants. The Sydney aquarium is amazing and well worth the entrance fee. Make sure you go on the Monorail, do the round trip, before it fades away into oblivion. A shame because as a tourist attraction it is quite unique.Take a ferry trip and soak up the beautiful scenery, or take a white knuckle ride on one of the jet boats, either way you'll have fun.
Not a bad walk. Darling Hbr is a decent walk from the Opera House and Circular Quay. Mostly filled with cafes and restaurants, definitely consider a stop by the Maritime Museum.
Amy G. Such a choice for eateries - and some most economical. Loads to see and do. Activities abound and people openly friendly
What Sydney is all about!. Great place, water views, amazing selection of dining - a dream place for a sunny afternoon in Sydney!
Lots of nice restaurants. Lovely place to walk around after dinner, or sit and have a coffee or an ice cream, felt very safe even late at night.

Better than Circular Quay. We thought Darling Harbour was better than Circular Quay! It is full of restaurants and shops set around the most beautiful Harbour formally Cockle Bay. There are the land trains that go along taking people from one end to the other and a mono rail goes around the top if you want to go further afield. All the ferries come there but it is not as manic as Circular Quay. At the weekend there are street entertainers and fireworks. There is an Imax cinema with an enormous screen. We loved the aquarium with the sharks. The Koala at the wildlife centre. We loved eating at Ciren, sitting out watching the Harbour lights was wonderful.
Lots of restaurants/attractions. Lots of restaurants, the Aquarium, the IMAX Theatre, Madam Tussaud, and the Wildlife World are located here.

Superb location. The Darling Harbour area has everything. It is beside the water serviced by Sydney ferries & the other ferry operators. It is a brilliant area for walking with great atmosphere & it is well lit & safe at night. It has the Aquarium, Madame Tussards, the IMax. It has the cafes & bars at Cockle Bay Wharf & King Street Wharf. There is a great outdoor play area for all age groups, plenty of water features & the Chinese Garden of Friendship if you feel like some quiet time.It is a great area to visit & has plenty of hotels in the area.

Great to Take the kids. Have been there several times but we have found that with the kids its okay but just the two of us then we tend to stay away. Although one year we were there for the boat show and it was awesome what they had done to the harbour.

A tourist haven. On this visit to Darling Harbour we chose to eat at King Street Wharf with their huge choice of restaurants.We also visited the newly opened Madame Tussard's wax works which is located near the Aquarium. Although not as large as London's Madame Tussard's it is neverthe less well worth a visit.
Fantastic sight seeing destination.. Darling harbour is brilliant. We really enjoyed the vibrant atmosphere, there are many restaurants, bars and activities, including just watching the world go by.

Vibrant, breathtaking location but restaurants disappointing. Darling Harbour is a terrific place to visit. Packed with restaurants, the biggest iMax theatre in the world, and so much more. When the weather is good (which is most of the year) this place is magical. The only disappointment are the restaurants. I've been to most of them and have found the quality of the food a little disappointing. It's almost as if they don't wish to try hard enough because they have guaranteed business through tourists.

Water and things to see. stayed here for a night, easy to walk around, lots of food and drinks, and lot of attractions we didn't get time to see the next day. Would like to spend another day looking at boats and things. City lights abound if that's your thing.

Great Bustling Place at Night. We caught the Ferry Over to Darling Harbour from Circular Quay it took about 30mins. We saw on the Internet that there were fireworks on Saturday Nights so went to check them out. They started at 8.30pm they only lasted about 15mins but they were great got some great pictures and film footage. It was busy but you could still walk about comfortable. There are plenty of Restaurants and Bars here. It's got a great atmosphere too. There's also Madame Tusadds, Sea Life Centre, A Widlife Centre just a few of the things here there is a lot more to do. Definitely worth a visit there when in Sydney.

Absolutely Gorgeous. This was one of my favourite places in Sydney, it is stunning. I was speechless when I first saw it. Wide range of resturants and bars offering a wide variety of cuisines. If you have chidren there is plenty to keepthem amused here too.Its is definately a must see place in Sydney.

The heart of Sydney. If you go to Sydney, Darling Harbour is a must-go place or you've never been to Sydney. The view of the Opera House and Harbour Bridge is amazing. There are a lot of restaurants, cafes, pubs and clubs along Darling Harbour, there is even a train-like ride for you to get from one point to another. However it would be more awesome if the ride is free. It costs $5 per adult. It could be cheaper. On certain Saturday nights, there is a fireworks display at the harbour so if you are lucky, you get to see it.

Good people watching. Liked the fact that the restaurants had their menus posted, easy to walk around, found the naval museum confusing. Good people watching. Actually found it to be closer to the Central Business area than I thought it was. There was really no need to take the ferry from the Circular Quay to Darling Harbour except that it did allow you to sail under the bridge.

Loved it. Even though we stayed in the Rocks, we took a leisurely walk to Darling Harbour one afternoon. Plenty to see and do - the Maritime Museum, shopping, pubs, and some great waterfront dining. Another must while in Sydney.

Darling harbour - not so darling after all. Darling harbour was over crowded, over priced and unexciting. There were many restuarants, but the only good food was the ice-cream. Rather try the Chinese Garden of Friendship nearby.

Restaurant Paradise. In addition to numerous other attractions, there's an unbelievable selection of fine waterfront restaurants with outdoor seating. There's almost too much choice and it's hard to narrow it down to just one - particularly if there's more than two in your party. The happenin' place for a pleasant evening meal.

Nice place to walk & Enjoy. Well its well made and had quite a few dining areas including an Indian restaurant, so got some Indian vegetarian food after a long time...It also has the Madame Tussad and the Zoo where you can see the Kangaroos if you don't have time to go out of city
Time and time again. We found ourselves back there many times during our trip either for the attractions , food or the theatre

Forget it. I don't like Darling Harbour - it feels plastic. The Maritime Museum is the only saving grace. The restaurants are terrible. You can get a nice expensive drink at a bar - often with a noisey, intoxicated crowd.

Food and drinks. Darling harbour is full of restaurants which are a little pricey but the view at night from them is worth every penny. There is the sea life centre at the harbour which is absolutely amazing. We were there for 3 hours, it was fantastic.

VERY expensive restaurants. Darling Harbour is well worth a visit and a stroll along the walkways. We walked from Darling Harbour to the Harbour Bridge, to The Rocks, Circular Quay, the Opera House and then onto the Botantical Gardens. About 5 kms but really enjoyable.We returned to Darling Harbour for dinner but nealry died when we saw the prices. Ended up at I Thai and had a $19 meal each... Only one course. It was about the cheapest we could find. So Darling Harbour is a bit of a tourist trap but certainly worth seeing.

Excellent family venue. Darling Harbour is great for adults and children. Plenty of open spaces and fountains for the kids to play. Lots of restaurants / cafes that cater for adults and/or children. You can spend hours here and then have a nice meal.
Would give it a miss. If you are stuck for time I would give this a miss. It has the convention centre but it is a bit drab and plastic . There are far nicer places to walk around to be honest
Excellent dining options. We love darlling harbour for its many restaurants and bars. So much better than those around circular quay. We love Nicks and I'm Angus. Fab food, fab views, fab service.

Lovely!. Really nice harbour with lots going on, there are lots of attractions like wildlife world, sealife sydney etc and a visitor centre. Really nice at night too with lots of bars and a large variety of restaurants to choose from, definitely worth a visit!
Another great place in Sydney. Not as famous as the Opera House and what not, this place has a lot to offer as well. Definitely come down here and try and go to the aquarium and zoo.
Friday evening was fun here. with a lot of restaurants, bars, entertainers and young people Friday night was a lot of fun here. It looks clean, looks safe and felt great.
Brilliant place. Terrific place to visit and loads going on and a great tourist information centre and if you buy the tour bus ticket there it is slightly cheaper.

Great Place To Be. Love Darling Harbour we usually stay at the Casino we we go to Sydney and the Darling Harbour is only a short distance away we love the restaurants the shopping and Darling Harbour must see.
Fireworks. We went down to Darling Harbour on a Saturday night, mainly to watch the fireworks, and we weren't disappointed. Some of the best we have seen. Lots of places to eat, pretty pricey tho.

Skip the harbour get Gelato at The Star Casino. The Harbour itself is nice, but our favorite was the Tiramisu Gelato at the Star Casino - best thing we ate in Sydney.
The Harbour has a lot of restaurants - looked tasty but very expensive. Besides that, the harbour has the zoo (do not recommend it), aquarium, and wax museum. Seems like a good place to take your kids.

Lots to see. Darling Harbour has to be one of my favourite places. We've been to Sydney 3 times and each time we've stayed at hotels within a short walk. There are so many places to eat or just sit and watch the world go by. The IMax Theatre and Chinese Gardens are worth a visit and if you have children, the play area at Tumbalong Park is a must. There's a little train service which does a circuit of the harbour going all the way along to the Chinese Gardens for $5 per adult. Other places at Darling Harbour include Madame Tussauds, Sydney Aquarium, The Maritime Museum and Wildlife Australia. The monorail is handy to use though I believe it's leaving Sydney within the next few months which is a shame. You can board cruise boats there too - so much to do in one area and I haven't yet mentioned the shopping centre.

Tons to do here. Great choice of restaurants for all tastes. Nicely landscaped with places to sit and rest and people watch. The big entertainment Center is here. Lots of pedestrian walkways/overpasses. Edge of Chinatown/king street wharf. Very central.
Great place. Fantastic place to spend an afternoon, all the attractions, shopping and restaurants, you would walk your feet off and still not have seen everything

What is there not to like about it?. Darling Harbour is alive and vibrant. It has clean, wide walkways along the harbour. Many many restaurants to choose from as well as starbucks, McDonalds and Subway for those with younger families or wanting to eat on the run. A playground and some seating areas for picnics. Also has an array of activities from Chinese Garden of Friendship, aquarium, maritime museum plus many others. It you like things quieter then visit during the week.The only downside for us was the amount of people smoking... would be much nicer if they made this a smoke free venue.

Individual Sydney Area. There is so much to see in Sydney but Darling Harbour deserves a visit on it own due to its newness and buzzy atmosphere.Great for just a walk around for the views and lot of eating places.
Restaurants galore. great place to sit and people watch with a lot of variety. Pub in the mall wasn't obliging with service so we went to a Tapas bar and enjoyed the view.
thoughtfully renovated. Bright and cheery place. There is a little train that will trundle you around the area for $5 each. In the heat this is very welcome. Loads of bars/restaurants.

Avoidable. Darling Harbour is just way too touristy for my liking... Bustling with crowds, lots of average bars and restaurants around, average views. Circular Quay and other areas of Sydney are just so much better. Highly avoidable, unless you just want to visit to tick off your list.
Nice place to visit. Lots of places to shop and eat at. Take in the zoo there. Really neat. Beautiful harbor. Wish I had more time here and I would have taken in the wax museum

Love darling habour. Its a spraling habour with lots to do, very touristy as you would expect, the restaurants are very expensive and there are better places to eat, but on a sunny day, we really enjoyed hanging out here.

Busy, with loads of buzz. Loads to see and do around the Harbour, we took the ferry from the Quay as the easiest route. Really busy at the weekend but plenty of bars and restaurants, cinema and attractions or just people watching

Vibrant and fun place to go. Arrived in Sydney on a Saturday morning, checked into hotel and went 'exploring' We 'found' the Harbour early evening and were delighted to have so many places to eat and drink. We ate in a fish restuarant sitting outside and enjoyed watching everyone 'promenading'. The food was good but we thought it was expensive, as was the case with most places we ate in Sydney. As dusk fell, street entertainers came out and we enjoyed watching dancers, magicians, musicians etc. After we has eaten we joined others sitting out on the harbour steps to watch the firework display - which was pretty spectacular. Everyone was so friendly and there was a party atmosphere. Our hotel was a short walk away and we stopped for an ice cream on walk back which made the perfect end to the evening. Great childrens play area close by too, with loads of unusual things to keep them occupied. Would definately go back here if we go back to Sydney,
Foodie heaven. What a trendy little place! Heaps of cute places to eat and go to the movies, play skirmish or go bowling!

Another side of Sydney. this is the place to go if you want to view the Maritime Museum, enjoy a multi-ethnic food court, or take a monorail ride into the heart of Sydney. The nearby Chinese Garden of Friendship is a wonderful side trip and not to be missed.
dinner at darling harbour. Many restaurants to choose from in a lovely location. Had some enjoyable seaford and then had dessert at the lindt chocolate restaurant.

Lots to do and see - but watch the food. There's no doubting that Darling Harbour is an exciting place for visitors, with lots of attractions and things to do and see day and night. For me the detracting fact is that food in the area is generally not all that good and very expensive for what you get. So eat nearby - say Chinatown - instead of at Darling Harbour.
Darling of a harbour. Excellent venue lots to do and good choice of resturants also maritime museum and reasonable shopping centre enjoyed the trip on the monorail
Very pleasant surprise. Darling Harbour is a quite modern area, with work ongoing. It is full of cafes, bars and entertainment venues.
Beautiful Darling Harbour. Definitely our favourite place to go daytime or in the evening, plenty of restaurants to choose from.

Designed for the Tourist. Such a happening place designed with the tourist in mind. Great bars and restaurants (though expensive), which are fine for people watching. The fountains and water features add to it being a throughly enjoyable location and traffic free!
Very special. You have to visit Darling Harbour if you go to Sydney! A lovely place wiht lots of restaurants and places to take a coffee/beer.

Perfect for an evening stroll. The buzz was great. Loaded of families out enjoying the water features with their kids. (nice to see that they were "allowed" to play in the water bits!) Restaurants galore, clean and a nice feel. Fab
Bliss. Best place loved dining on the waterfront fireworks on Saturday. Pure bliss. Plenty to do. People watching. Tones of food to choose from. So want to go back

Lovely place to be!. Went here for my birthday meal and it looked beautiful at night, all lit up and the lights reflecting in the water. There was even a firework display from the harbour (they must have known it was my birthday!) and that was spectacular.

Not a shopping highlight. Darling Harbour has lost it's shopping magic, it's now more of a place to go visit, see the sights (Aquarium, Madam Tussuade, etc) but if you want to buy anything make the walk south to Paddy's Haymarket - much cheaper and much more fun.

Very nice place to walk. Spent a morning in Darling Harbour admiring the sites then visited the Chinese Garden and the Maritime Museum. Both were great and this was a very easy walk from the Circular Quay where I was staying.
Shops, Movie theatre, restaurants and more. .. Good for strolling around and the Aquarium is located at one end of the complex. Some restaurants were closed and shops seemed a bit tired. .

50/50. Yeah and no...
Yes it's nice and have fireworks on Saturdays
But i don't have that attachment as, say, with the Rocks
The area is completely overpriced with no many good places to eat. Shopping centre isn't good at all...
Though King St wharf is a good place to party on a weekend

A great place to be!. Darling Harbour is a fascinating part of Sydney. We took the Hop-on, Hop-off double decker tour bus ($30 Seniors) and got off here for several hours. They have an abundance of shops, museums, restaurants, and bars. Everything is spotless and immaculate! Allow time for a visit here, you won't regret it.
Great for food. We spent a few evenings here out for dinner and it was a nice walk around the harbour when dark. Lots of good restaurants and people watching to be had...

dd. ddhis area has so much to offer. You can spend a whole day exploring it. There is the Sealife Aquarium, another must see. There are many wonderful restaurants through the wharfs. The setting is beautiful with the Chinese Gardens, a great architectural design and easy access to transportation. Don't miss it.

NEED MORE TIME. Really enjoyed returning to Darling Harbour after living in Brisbane for 12 years. It has expanded and the restaurant area on the eastern side offers great varirty. A tourist place to visit also for locals.

Excellent in every way. This area has so much to offer. You can spend a whole day exploring it. There is the Sealife Aquarium, another must see. There are many wonderful restaurants through the wharfs. The setting is beautiful with the Chinese Gardens, a great architectural design and easy access to transportation. Don't miss it.
Darling Harbour. Try the monorail to this area...quick and convenient. Good attractions...The Aquarium and Maritime museum. Nearby are Paddy's mrkets and Chinatown
Nice place to stroll around & enjoy the walk. A good place to hang out with friends or family. Many people jog during the day & many good places to dine as well.

Water taxi tour. it was rainy that day but didn't damped our spirits Beautiful Harbor and we wanted a tour of the surrounding areas of the Harbor. we talked to a water taxi and he wasn't busy so he took us all over and it was perfect!
A Lively Place. Really enjoyed staying in Darling Harbour, so much going on and so many nice restaurants to try and not too far to walk to the QVB, Pitt Street or the Rocks and Circular Quay.

So much to see, so much to do!. Darling Harbour is the heart of Sydney! A must visit when you are there. So much to do, so much to see. I loved hanging around there, watching people, having a ice cream or a caffe latte on one of the terraces. People performing arts and tricks, catching a ferry to one of the islands, zoo or other destinations. Always something happening, a great vibe!!

Always bright and beautiful. I have been going there for years and visited again recently Clean safe and tidy with lots of attractions. Harbourside centre with its shops and cafe's is always a must see as is Cockle bay wharf with its innumerable restaurants...I could go on....
Everything for everyone. Staf attractions, World Wildlife park, Harbourside restaurants, access to the monorail, cafes and shops, beautiful photo opportunities from the victorian style bridge.

Good For Tourists. It is a touristy place with Madame Tussauds, SEA LIFE Sydney Aquarium, and WILD LIFE Sydney Zoo. We visited Madame Tussauds and we had a dinner cruise. It is a good place for tourists to engage in touristy activities.

I love the buzz of Darling Harbour.. The area is always alive and features a huge choice of places to eat and drink and great prices. Stay at the Adina Harbour side Apartments for a great location close to the action. The new kids play ground is a treat and for a quite hour or two pop into the Japanese Gardens and enjoy the tranquility. Finish off the visit with some herbal tea and scones. Finally walk up the road 10 minutes to China Town and overindulge in a feed of pork and duck at one of the many small restaurants.

Lots of ways to spend money!. When Darling Harbour was first mooted in the 80's it was seen as a waste of money. it became a world leader in old dockyard renovations and the idea was copied all over the world. It has a multitude of attractions for the diner,drinker and spender. A must on any visitors itinerary. The Australian Maritime Museum,the Sydney Aquarium.and many more attractions are all with-in walking distance.Access is by walking ,tram,bus or ferry. There is something for everyone!
Very touristy and expensive. Busy and expensive as you'd expect, but worth a half day trip and if you have kids there's a lot on offer.
Loved the aquarium. Darling harbour is a must see in Sydney. Loved the aquarium. The wildlife world (owned by same people) is good, but no where near as good as Featherdale.

Lively, busy, great. Darling Harbour is the place to be when you visit Sydney, loads of sea front bars and restaurants and clubs. Full of life, you can catch some ferries here too. Water Taxi's operate in addition to the monorail, however this is being deleted in June 2013. You can expect to pay a little more for food in Darling Harbour, but you can also get some good deals too. Dont visit Sydney and miss it.
great times. great bars ,great restaurants great views, just one warning beware of ITS 5 O CLOCK SOMEWHERE BAR its a rip off

public music and parties for new year. I traveled to sydney during christmas when many parties are orginized, I saw a lot of people go to darling harbour for their parties, they dressed very nice and sexy. and this area is very expensive during this time of the year. But lovely to see people are happy. Also, if you have kids you can take them to darling harbour because they have small park next to harbour so you can let kids playing with water or some exercises places here.

Fabulous area in Sydney - has something for everyone!. Darling Harbour is a fabulous spot in Sydney just a short stroll away from China Town and the CBD. Bustling with people of all ages, there is a beautiful scenic walkway by the harbour with tons of wonderful restaurants, bars, and cafes. Not to be missed are the Lindt and Guylian chocolate stores both serving tasty treats and beverages. For families, there is a great park/playground to keep the kids busy and an aquarium and iMax for more entertainment. On weekends, there are always free festivals of various sorts. Definitely one of my favourite spots in Sydney.

FUN FOR KIDS AT DARLING HARBOUR. In the summer, the water park here is excellent. It caters for kids of all ages.... from 2 to 12 I reckon. Eating places abound (with a range of levels). Restaurants can be expensive at night. A ferry ride from Darling Harbour to Circular Quay is a must.

Lots to do and see !. An excellent place to start a visit to Sydney. Loads of good reasonably priced places to eat for the tourist as well as more expensive gorgeous fish restaurants. The Martime Museum was fascinating, especially the ships and boats moored in the harbour. Lovely to be away from traffic and enjoy the sights.
