My favourite spot in Sydney. So many wonderful Restaurants, Pubs and Attractions so close to the city and harbour...The atmosphere is always pumping here...Go on a sunny day
Tacky. Not the greatest place in Sydney. Plethora of average restaurants. The whole place seemed rather tacky to me.

Another Sydney Landmark. GO.. You must visit Darling Harbour if you are in Sydney. You can walk it (15-20 minutes) from Sydney Harbour. Lots of restaurants, cafes, etc. Also, the wax museum, the little zoo and the tiny aquarium are there (not highly recommended: they are miniatures attractions for tourists). Strolling the harbour at night is relaxing. Go.

Harbour. Loved the restaurants, the attractions the calm atmosphere which I didnt expect. It was a lovely relaxing place and plenty of shopping if you go to Harbour side. Check out the Submarine at the wharf.
Go explore.... Take in the Sydney Aquarium and Wild Life Sydney. It's a fun activity especially if it's raining outside.
Great stay. The heart of Sydney. Fun, a little bit touristic but one of the heart of your trip: circular quay, opera and the bridge everything in one place.
Love, love, love. Darling Harbour is one of my favourite places to go in Sydney. There are great restaurants, bars and it's just lovely to sit and enjoy the sun.

Must see in Sydney. Not a trip to Sydney would be complete without taking a walk and maybe a dinner or lunch in Darling Harbour. It is one of the prettiest parts of the city, with so many restaurants and so much entertainment, even the (now just over year old) Hard Rock Cafe found a better location there.

Disappointing.. The whole area is contrived, tacky and touristy. There is nothing authentic about it and it seems like no Sydneysider would ever go there, which makes it feel like all the tourists have been shepherded to this one area. The eateries are hugely expensive and lacking in quality or initiative. The "attractions" are tourist traps.

Great way to kill time!. Lots of stuff to see. Great gelato, Starbucks and pizza place. Although the pizza place, located next to the gelato place, had rude service and was expensive - opt to just order from the take away window and sit on the dock, I recommend the salmon pizza and the patata pizza - delicious! There are other places to eat which looked just as appealing. A few bars.

Lovely harbour, lots to see. The harbour was great, there is a sealife centre and Madame tussauds on the quay side. There was parties at the park, and we were here on Chinese new year so there were fireworks going off. We only stayed here for approx 8 hours as we were waiting to fly home. The only niggle I had was the price of food. I had fish and chips and my boyfriend had a burger and it cost us £50.00!!!! The drinks are quite cheap. But then again we were in a city and in the quay too. Overall we enjoyed the time here and I would visit again.

yes beautiful one day perfect the next. ive been many time to darling harbour and still cant get enough of the place as there is so much to do here from shopping to food to coffee to just relaxing and watching people go past a must place to see
Harbour area. Tourist area If you want to go to the aquarium then go but I think your time is better spent on Circle quay and other areas of Sydney
a must visit. This harbour a 5 minute walk from The Grace hotel,must have a meal in wine and steak bar (exspensive but nice).busy place loads of places to eat and drink and often visited by celabs.
Great resturants and view. Lovely spot to visit - every type of cuisine you can think of. Great view.Sadly the monorail to Darling Harbour is being closed down in Jun 2013.

great place. heaps of resturants and bars to try, beautiful spot to visit. Some nice shops there in the mall.Huge old boat done up into a resturant, they have fireworks on a saturday night so that is a bit of fun. mono rail is good though they are going to get rid of it in june this year

Tired and tacky. The Darling Harbour precinct is a nice place to go for a bit of a stroll. There's lots of places for a meal, the Seafood Markets and city are nearby and there's other attractions well worth a look. But the food is of a low standard and the shopping is terrible. This is really only worth visiting if you intend on checking out one of the theme parks or other attractions in the area.

Got Everything You Need. Looking for a great spot for after work or for dinner. Try Darling Harbour. It's got all kinds of foods and drinks. And if you need to shop for something, this place has it too. Great view of downtown Sydney with its illuminated buildings. Sit outside at any time of the year. Get there by the monorail, a great experience.

Plenty of places to see and visit.. A lovely and clean area with so many bars and restuarants, many deals to be sought.
A pleasant walk for all ages !

Sydney. Total tourist area, but great place to watch people. Food is expensive but still good. A must place to see with major attractions such as the Aquarium and Imax. Go if you have time just to be a good tourist.

Let's go and see ships and people. Loved the ambience and life in the Harbour area. Lots of things to see and hear apart from impressive cruise boats. Also the walk to the opera house is worthwhile at any time of the day.Great entertainment as well with "freelance" artists performing.

Must visit when in Sydney. Loved the ambience, the choice of restaurants and cafes. Great place during the day for kids of all ages. Beautiful kids area with water fountains and wet play area. Something for everyone in the family including Imex theater, small zoo and aquarium.
Expensive bars but the happening place!. Nice place to chill and people watch in one of the many bars. Its a shame the monorail is being scrapped as it is unique.

A very laid back place. A veery laid back place during the day! Check out the interesting water fountains. People watching is fun! Food and drink are expensive to choose wisely! Take your time enjoy the public art.

people watchers heaven. we had plenty of time in darling harbour as we were waiting for our grandson.saw plenty of joggers.What a place to jog.All the lovely restaurants.Watching the boats go in and out .it was great

Food options are endless... Within walking distance to the motel we were staying at Darling Harbour was a great place to walk and explore. Large range of activities to do here and i strongly suggest checking out the National Maritime Museum.

A must see. Darling Harbour has many wonderful restaurants, mainly expensive, but there are also other casual eating places. It is worth a walk around and you will find the Aquarium and Casino nearby. You can take ferry rides from there.

Intimate mini harbour. Darling Harbour's like a mini version of the main Sydney Harbour. I like the wide range of al fresco dining opportunities. Some places are a bit overpriced for the quality of the food and service. The location and views are great. The parkland area at the Western edge is pleasant. There's a great kids playground there and also lots of fountains for the young and young at heart to play around near (or in!).
The area I would go to if thinking about suicide. I found this area really depressing. Why did the Australians have an enormous yellow plastic duck floating in the water ?

Wonderful morning walks. Loved the early morning walks along Darling Harbour waterfront it's great. Such a beautiful area. Had lunch at one of the many restaurants. So much to do there and it has a real vibe.
Darling Harbour. If you are looking for night life, this is the spot. That place is hoppoing. There are boat tours and events throughout the day.

Never fails to impress even on a rainy day!. We planned a special day with lunchtime cruise to be the highlight. The cruise was not good but the experience of Darling Harbour was the highlight. We drank wonderful coffee at Cafe de Nico, peered out at people coping with the rain, and ran for cover with everyone else. The dragon boat races provided free entertainment. There was a wonderful "buzz" as we all made the most of the weather along with thousands of others. We shared delicious icecream, drank more coffee and headed for home on a train. We will do this again. Everyone who lives in Sydney can enjoy an inexpensive outing anytime!

much to see. convenient food and drinks. nice ferry ride from circular quay. the wildlife sydney zoo is there with koalas no less. the maritime museum is a short walk. the lite rail is a good way to see the downtown area - however the tickets are not a part of the regular transportation - so more fees.

Nice area to visit in Sydney. Darling Harbour is worth a visit when in Sydney. If staying in Circular Quay area, you can actually walk there in 20 - 30 minutes. If you walk across the Harbour Bridge, you can then take a ferry from Luna Park to Darling Harbour. The hop-on/hop-off sightseeing bus also has a stop there.There are a number of indoor/outdoor cafes there where you could have lunch, dinner, or enjoy happy hour in a pleasant setting. It was not particularly crowded when we were there.If you are looking for the Hard Rock Cafe, this is where it's located.
Maritime Museum just superb. Lots to see, do, explore and experience. The rest of Darling Harbour is just a lot of shops but the Maritime Museum is a true gem.

things to do & places to go. There is lots to do in Darling Harbour! We had yummy Gelato one day, visited Wild Life park the next day, just strolled around beautiful fountains and water features, had dinner, shopped, the list could go on...
Good restaurants and good place to relax. on a nice day, sit on the stairs watching the beautiful landscape of sydney downtown. few good restaurants to have lunch and dinner

great place to spend some time. Darling Harbour is so far my favourite place in Sydney. There is so much to see and do in the area it is hard to chose. You can watch a match on the floating footy pitch, go on a sub at the maritime museum, check out the creatures of the sea life and wildlife centres or have your picture taken with celebs at Madame Tussauds. There are also a lot of reasonably priced restaurants and the world famous Hard Rock Cafe ... I feel a new tshirt is needed.
beautiful harbour. beautiful harbour, great for photography with the reflections in the water.The cafes can be quite pricey, but well worth it. Theres a very big cinema and the aquarium

my favourite place to chill. I visited Darling Harbour everyday of my two week visit to Sydney. I was staying near Hyde Park so it was a 15 minute walk from my hotel. In the Darling Quarter area there is free wifi so I was able to stay connected to my family and friends. The shops are open everyday until 9pm, convenient for shopping after a day of sightseeing. And then there's the tourist attractions, the Sydney Aquarium, Wild Life Sydney, Madame Tussards etc, something for everyone. I was there the day the rubber duck came into the Harbour for the Sydney Fest, very cool to see 60,000 people show up to see it that day. During certain times of the year there are events lined up and fireworks on Saturday nights. Check out their website to see what exciting events will be during your visit.
Outstanding Views. Darling Harbor is a gem. Inviting water front with appealing skyline. Many restaurant choices and sometimes local entertainment. A must-do if you come to Sydney.
BBQ restaurant where you cook your own steak. Don`t order fillet steak here. It has loads of gristle and when you complain the DUMBOS tell you that`s how fillet is! DOH!!

Wonderful place!. A huge variety of restaurants, cafes and bars to choose from all with very very reasonable/competitive prices, serving really yummy food! Surrounded by the clean and beautiful jetty - would come back here again!

What a darling. Only had four days stay in Darling but what a lovely bay, lots of places to eat, and lovely play area from any one with children. Things to do the maritime museum, waxworks, imax, and aquarium. Use the ferry to get around lovely.

Feels like a tourist shopping mall. Superficially it looks like a lot to appeal - lots of restaurants, cafes, shops all surrounding a lovely water aspect but it is not something we would visit as a Sydney sider.Often come here with overseas and interstate visitors when there is a trade event or conference on nearby but that is more because of convenience than because of natural appeal.

Great place to vissit. I went in to Darling Harbour looking for something to eat, it was a hive of activity I could not believe that there would be so many people out and about on a Sunday evening, it was great to see.I have not been there for some years and did notice that there is a massive play area for kids before you get into the water area, again a great idea and great area.I had a wonderful meal on a veranda of the Festival Marketplace and watched the world go by, most enjoyable.Overall a great place to visit.
All in one place. This place contains multiple attractions.The jetty is maintained clean with tourist shops. The approach through the sky bridge is lovely.

Excellant to Chill Out. Amazing view and breeze. Just a good place to relax and dine at the many bistro. After a long walk touring Sydney, Darling Harbour was just too good to sit back, relax and chat with friends and family and have 1 glass or two.
Beautiful !. Very nice area, tons of restaurants and bars beside, and a small shopping mall. Very beautiful view! Very clean!

Location, location！. Two weekends ago, we went to this Eat Love Pizza for lunch, and we had a great time.The location is wonderful, has a lovely beautiful harbor view, the deal was amazing .And the food was excellent as well, good , fresh ingredients, wonderful pizza, we had salmon pizza and meat lover pizza, they were very tasty and simply delightful!Also the service was quite good too the two young ladies were helpful and very patient (we had a 3 year old with us).We had a great time and this place is just perfect for the family!Overall it was an excellent experience and we recommend this place for everyone.

Really dated. The restaurants and bars were nice, it would probably look nicer at night when it is all lit up and you can't see how dated the buildings on the opposite side of the Harbour are - they all look a bit daggy now
sunny haven. cracking small harbour with loads of bars and restraunts. great little area to wind up the day and watch the world go by.

Lost its charm?. Maybe we've been too often - Darling Harbour is not the place it used to be. Yes it still has the tourist attractions on the city side, eating establishments, bars etc. - but to us it seems tired - the shopping in the plazas on the western side is not the vibrant busy place it used to be. Worth a visit if you haven't seen it - or want to take in the tourist attractions (mini zoo, aquarium etc). W prefer the rocks

Darling Harbour the place to Visit !!!!. Darling Harbour is a great place to visit and i visit every time i'm in Sydney. There is loads of Bars and Restaurants to choose from. You also have the i max theatre.Chinese garden of friendship is worth a visit.And you also have Sydney Aquarium and Sydney Wildlife World and you can walk from the Ferry Terminal right round to Paddy's Market great few days worth

the other harbour!. visited with friends many times during our three week stay.a lively area with much to offer everyone plenty of resturants with a good selection of food.plenty for families to do with some free play area's including free films shown certain times of year and spectacular firework displays on weekends during december i believe.often overlooked,worth the walk.Paddy's market close by for those souveniers!

Why else visit Sydney?. Amazing - such a hive of activity, restaurants and shops plus the Aquarium is the highlight - When arriving and departing in Sydney i stayed in Darling Harbour and still talk of it to this day
Lively meeting place. Always something going on,great bars and restaurants - particularly like the walk round to Paddy's Market

Nice walk to see great spots around. Its quiet interesting to walk around with many choices of bars and restaurants.. Start from imax and you walk all the way to star casino over the bridge with great views of central business district..
Wonderful afternoon and evening. Beautiful to walk outside for all ages. Lovely playground for children and restaurants, bars, and stores at all price levels for adults.

Darling Harbour -Lots to See and Do. Darling harbour is host to The maritime Museum, The Powerhouse museam and Sydney aquarium. All great places to visit for Kids and Ddults alike. There is also the Chinese garden and many many places to eat. The only negative is the over the top prices in some of the eateries but discerning people will work this out as they walk around. Its also easy to get to by a short walk from trains, by monorail or by ferry from Circular Quay
Lots to Like. Always seemed to have a buzz and because of Sydney Festival, the big Duck was there. Lots of varied restaurants, with kids menus. Generally nice and a good add-on to the Aquarium

Fantastic.. Darling Harbour was very busy, but so scenic and loads going on. Lots of shops, places to eat and you could even cool off in the water features which were scattered around. Enjoyed seeing the large yellow rubber duck.
Touristy but never gets old. The Harbour is very kitschy and full of people, but even as a local/frequent visitor I never get sick of it. Plus there are fireworks every Saturday night - a must do.

Gorgeous Harbor with lots of activities, food, and people. Sydney Harbor is a bustling place with lots of action. The ferries that go to many places leave from there, so there are long lines (on a weekend) to board. There are restaurants and shops and of course many great panoramic views of the harbor, the Sydney Harbor Bridge, the Sydney Opera House, and the city itself. It is a nice walk and next to the large Botanic Gardens too. One of the main sights of the beautiful city of Sydney..

Chinese Gardens. Darling Harbour is fun to walk through with its carnival atmosphere. There are tons of places to eat, rides for children, and impromptu shows. My favorite spot was the Chinese Garden. There is a $5.00 entrance fee, but worth it. The gardens are peaceful and beautiful with lovely trees, plants, and a waterfall.

View! Restaurants! Shopping! Museums! People Watching!. The Darling Harbour area of Sydney has a LOT to offer. In Sept 2012 we stayed in a rental apartment in Pyrmont and walked daily to the area. I highly recommend the area to dine, catch a whale-watching cruise, explore the museums, shop, and of course, people watch.

Best place in Sydney. You can all the tourist attractions under one roof, buy tickets for all four spots and get a discount. Elders can take a tram cart around the harbor if you get tired walking.Madame Tausads, aquarium, sea world ,it has it all

A great place!. This area has developed well over the last few years and is bustling with great restaurants and other attractions. Need not cost a lot of money either as there are picnic areas and water facilities for the young children

Choices!. Excellent location with a huge variety of diners, bars, clubs including IMAX cinema. There's always some festival or the other going on and a short walk across pyrmont bridge takes you to the rocks.

If you love shopping malls. You will probably enjoy Darling harbour but it's got nothing on Copenhagen and most vendors in the shop complex are there to generate revenue. I also found the Chinese restaurant inside on the 1st floor? to have very mediocre service and exceptionally pricey dishes. The ribs place there has the longest queuing time and the most arrogant monkeys at reception.

a bit touristy but a few great bars- restaurants. Great to take in the people and harbor sites. We walked along the entire harbour permitter to take in the sites of the many different restaurants and shops. Some great boats in the harbour as well.

Only if you must!. Yikes !! where do I start? being a Sydneysider I am embarrassed by this eyesore !! it looks like a mish mash of all that is ugly... businesses here are floundering for a reason, no one that is a local would recommend a friend going here... the ONLY good thing about Darling Harbour is it's proximity to China Town! I have to come here once or twice a year to attend trade fairs and I am always relieved to get out of this ghastly place.

Quite the happening place!. The place is huge and if you can't find something to eat here your not really hungry. Lots of people and very pretty at night. When we visited the yellow rubber duck drew quite the audience.
"A nice place to hangout". Alot of nice places to eat & things to do. A good place to hangout & watch the sights. Tram & buses are within walking distance.
Best place in Sydney. I loved Darling harbour, there's always things going on and loads of nice bar and restaraunts. The IMAX cinema is also worth visiting.

Great place. great for tourists and families and even locals to wander around and see the beautiful sights, eat some food, maybe see a movie. The kids can play at the park and there are water features to cool things down and let the kids paddle in.
Always a happening place!. Lots of choices for dining experiences. Huge variety in restaurants and cafes. Good shopping, gorgeous place. Must see for tourists.
A must when in sydney. This place is one of sydneys icons and has been for many years, there is so much shopping, restaurants, the aquarium.a must see for any tourists in sydney.

Sydney's most lively place. The best place to pass time in Sydney. Good food, lots of play areas for kids, great food outlets. Weekend nights are very busy and great to watch the youth of Sydney in the best of their fashions. I and my husband dearly love sitting by the harbour and watching the crowds whilst enjoying gourmet food
Vibrant Heart of Sydney Nightlife. A wonderful, pulsating centre where locals and visitors alike can live it up night after night. Made my 60-year-old bones feel young again!
Good for people watching. Sit at one of the many bars or restaurants and people watch. Lots of restaurants suited to many budgets. Free entertainment often which is an added bonus.
Great place to hang out. Everything! Shops rests and bars! Very hip and alive the place to enjoy and have a good bite. Recently the place was greatly developed more shops and resto

Much to see and do.. There is Madame Tassauds, Wildlife zoo, maratime museum and aquariuam to visit, all really well worth seeing. There are plenty of places to eat as well. Checkout all the big boats that are tied up here too.

Beautiful. I love darling harbour! Always lots to do. Eateries for all budgets, overlooking the water. Lots of activities. Shops to buy anything your heart desires, once again at all different budgets. Motels are close by allowing walking and not relying on public transport

Spots to relax or to party. Loved the open areas with seating in the middle of the walkways, where people could sit and relax while people watching, and avoid all the activity that everyone else was enjoying!

Enjoyable in the sun. It was odd to cross the road and to find this area open up to unveil a large childrens play area for all ages and shallow water area with fountains, that is surrounded by a variety of food eateries to provide for all styles. We visited at midday and everything was open, but was extremely busy and everything is overpriced, but we did not mind too much as we sat with a large ice cream watching children happily splashing around in the water, sunning ourselves then watching a variety of street performers break dancing, performing magic, playing instruments. There was also a mall on the left side of the harbour and we found a cheap deli counter where we got half chicken, chips and salad for like $6 and ate outside in the sunshine watching the world go by.

Wonderful Area!. We were so impressed with Darling Harbour. Lots to see and do, plenty of eateries and open air.The unexpected treat were the numerous fountains for viewing and wading! So clever and captivating. Perfect for all ages, and if you've got little ones, they will LOVE the fountains where you can play in the water.Huge variety of eateries and things to see. The Aquarium is awesome (don't miss). For the Sydney Festival (January), they floated in a HUGE yellow rubber ducky, and anchored it in the Harbour. What fun!And the New Year's Eve fireworks included both a 9 pm children's show and a 12 a.m. show. We were very impressed with Darling Harbour.

Lots of places but no where to eat?. Didn't eat here as lack of vegetarian choices and all seemed overprices and packed. Found really nice Italian behind Maritime Museum - reasonable and really good service.

Sunday at Darling. We had two Darling experiences: watching the 5-story yellow rubber duck be towed into place for opening day of the Sydney Festival. That day, we also watched a charming pajama-clad kazoo band on the bridge & ate at the Thai restaurant there. Our second experience was stopping briefly there on the Captain Cook as part of a boat cruise from the Olympic area back to Circular Quay.
Loved it!. We felt Darling Harbour has a lot more to do than Syndey Harbour. It has far more Cafe's and Restaurants along the shore and is eaily walkable from the City Center.
Beautiful and Interesting. This lovely place has a spectacular view of the Opera House and a shopping/restaurant mall along the shore. Never have seen such large scallops and they were delicious.

2 day stopover. Great place for families to visit, plenty to see, wild life and sea centres, shops bars and a good choice of restaurants. we were lucky to see the switching of the christmas lights the start of the xmas celebrations on the harbour had a great time highly recommended.
Nick's Seafood. What a great restaurant in darling harbour, the seafood whilst on the pricy side was cooked superbly, the service did not miss a beat. Great evening with company.

Average. It depends on what you what to see in this part of Sydney, ether Wildlife World (zoo), the wax museum or the clubs and afew shops. Nice for a family for a day out if you have know where else to go.

Darling Harbour Sydney. All around the harbour are restaurants and bars. we went there many times but my favourite time was Saturday evening. At 9 o clock every Saturday they have a firework display from the middle of the harbour. The harbour is alight with colour and the display lasts about 10 minutes. Fantastic!!!1
lots to see. Many museums/ attractions are here and you can cross Pyrmont Bridge for scenic views. Plenty of Restaurants/ eateries and of course the rubber duck, which is very exciting for the kids.

Excellent Area. We stayed in this area during our visit to sydney and it is definitely one of the best areas to see/stay. The view was very good, with loads of choices for food and entertainment such as the Imax, aquarium etc. Also quite close to the China town, which a good place for some shopping and Chinese/Thai food. A must-Visit in Sydney.

I love the buzz!. It always seems busy in Darling Harbour! Filled with lots of energy and people! A must see and do on any visit to the city. The iconic sites are on the other bay, but the life is here!

Pretty - but for the tourists. Darling harbour itself is a pretty stretch of water to walk around or to sit beside. Take a visit to the Chinese gardens and eat a gelato sitting at the waters edge. There are free fireworks every Saturday night (around 9pm). Avoid the restaurants that line King Street wharf. The food is expensive for not great (what I'll call "tourist") quality. If you must eat, try the Cargo Bar. The shops on the other side of Darling Harbour are unexciting and several are touristy tat. The food court there is also not the best you'll find in Sydney

PLAY GROUND FOR THE LOCALS. IF ITS JUST SHOPPING FO RTH ETOURIST ITS ALL CONVENIENT AND PRICED TO TO MATCH THE CITYThe area is a great big playing field with swings, slides, Macca's and great big sand pits for the local childeren to pla. Good to let off steam if you have chikdren to burn enery Resturants are a bit pricey but you are on the water frontThe Chinese gardens is well worth the entry price for some in city serenityBut other than that its just a hub for shop owners to help tourist releave you of your money./ Conveniece at a price

Giant yellow duck. We visited Sydney during the Arts Festival - but the giant yellow duck was the only evidence we saw of the festival. The duck was floating beside the quay in the harbour and proved very popular with the tourists.Darling Harbour is the tourist entertainment area of Sydney and is bustling day and night. Here you will find a large number of restaurants and bars as well as the Sydney Aquarium, the Wildlife Centre, Madam Tussauds, the IMAX and boat tours of the harbour.Within a few hundred metres is Chinatown with it's wonderful variety of restaurants and Paddy's Markets where purchases ranging from mangoes to clothing can be made. The whole harbour area is circumnavigated by the monorail which is a novelty for tourists but doesn't extend far enough to be useful as a means of transport and is being closed in June 2013.

Sunset. In summer it is great to go down here late in the day.There are always a lot of activities and people doing interesting things.It is cool here after a hot day in the evening and great just to watch people while you relax.

Tourist trap. The area was a tourist trap and could be a little tacky. Walk through it once and you are good. Lots of children and families- so if you have kids and want to go to the wax museum or a fake zoo- this is the place for you. The best aspects were the many fountains and the Chinese Gradens.

Tourist Haven.. This is a very modern built up harbour lined with hotels, shops and restaurants. It is possible to get ferries from here to Sydney Harbour and other outlying areas. Personally I would not choose to stay here as it is really busy and touristy, but rather visit the Aquarium and go for a meal in one of the very good restaurants,

Great place for a stroll. I stay near the Darling harbour whenever I'm in Stdney and its a great place for an early morning walk and breakfast. The Imax and exhibition centres are here, but I love Home Bar and the meat and wine co to sit and watch (and eat). At night it turns into a bar and restaurant mecca, with plenty to do and see. Bungalow 8 and Cargo Bar are good for a drink and Steersons, Kobe Jones, Malaya and Nicks are great for a feed.

big day out in the city. I decided to take my 5 year old on the train to the city, we looked online what there was to see & do, we chose Darling Harbour & bought a Merlin annual pass online the night before, we went to Madame Tussaud's, the Wildlife Sydney zoo, Sea Life aquarium & then the Sydney Tower Eye! It was an awesome day out, very tiring thou so much walking, & the aquarium was flat out you could hardly move in there but that was the only downfall, all the other places were quite comfy to get around, my son got to drape a snake around his neck in the wildlife park he loved that, oh & we seen the huge yellow duck! highly recommend going there but be prepared for a lot of people, it was overcast most of the day thank god for that or it would of been a too hot...

Great Place to spend the afternoon. Lots to do , jump on a ferry with some fish and chips and sail around the harbour to get a real look at sydney, We got a weekly rail pass that gave us unlimited train, bus and ferry access and headed to Darling harbour, after boarding the ferry we got off and saw the giant rubber duck there for the Sydney Festival and then wandered around the harbour on the weekend there are street performers dotting around the cove and so many cafes/ restaurants to chose from you can be excused for being a little overwhelmed for choice or simply grab and ice-cream and just sit on the bank and watch the sites all in all a pleasant afternoon

Perfect for kids. We went to Darling Harbour in part to see the giant rubber duck floating there for a few weeks in January 2013. The incongruity of a huge yellow duck floating next to workaday ferries and sleek party boats added this element of ridiculous cuteness to a place already teeming with cute kids and their parents, not to mention an adorable real koala asleep in a eucalyptus tree outside Madame Taussauds. Darling Harbour has a great little amusement park for young children, with a carousel, playground, and various attractions geared toward families. Best of all, we went on a Sunday when the Family Fun Day pass is just $2.50 (Australian) per person to take the ferries all over. Definitely the bargain of the whole trip! Easy walking with a stroller, lots and lots of places to eat, lots of things to see.

Paradise. If you like just taking it all in and marvelling at positive atmospheres, good food and fun then you have to spend time in Darling Harbour both in the dylight and at night time. Enormous variety of food outlets [we did two evening restaurant meals that were wonderful and well priced]. Just go there and see how you feel when the sun goes and the lights in the CBD come up!

A lively centre with a lot going on. Brilliant there is so much going on day and night, that with an hour so so to while away Darling Harbour makes a great place to escape to, whether food, entertainment or just watching this is a great place to be.

Great area. This is a great all round place to visit. We took the hop on hop off , so got there in the day time for lunch and to shop, and went back the next evening for dinner, lots of choice , so take your time have a good look round before deciding where to eat. If your new to the area, you can easily walk into the city , so don,t need taxies.
Great!. Stunning area at night ~ the restaurants are a little pricey but well worth it for a special evening
Nice restaurants. Great choice of restaurants in this area and also a small but pleasant shopping centre, well worth the visit!

It's like a magnet!. I couldn't pull myself away from this place! :PI think we ate here about 8 times and didn't even make it through half of the good restaurants! There was a festival on also while we we're there which added to the amazing vews and atmosphere.
Good breakfast. Had really good breakfast at Plate. Enjoyed all the facilities for children,food court has excellent selection of food. Plenty to do there for kids and adults
Relaxing. Relaxing piece of harbour amongst all the crowdiness. Lovely to just sit and relax and enjoy some take out food.
Nice place to walk and dine. A must see! Lots of great restaurants around the harbour including the Hard Rock Cafe with great view.
Great Place to Hang Out. Darling Harbour is as good or not better than its cousin over at the Opera House. It has great restaurants, loads to see and do and is so convenient to the city centre

Cleaner and Quieter than Sydney Harbour. We preferred this harbour due to the fact that it seemed cleaner and quieter than Sydney Harbour. Very near the town centre and lots of activity around the harbour and some good walks.

Great restaurants on offer along with easy shopping. A great precinct with restaurants like Hurricanes (to die for pork ribs and steak), a great middle-eastern place with agilas (hubblybubbly) all on the Harbourside area. Then of course, Tokio Hotel, Blackbird, Pontoon on the otherside serve for nightlife along with the Imax Theatre.Shopping, there is general stores like Giordano, Glue, Temt, Cotton On, Typo along with australian souvenir shops. People finding Uggs or leather goods will definitely find it here.

Will Get Better. With the plans to upgrade this area things will only get better. Very much designed for the tourist and families during the day, there is a lot to see and do - Imax, museums, waxworks etc. Easy to access though best if coming from the harbour to use the ferries. Be prepared for lots of walking. Food areas have improved over the past 3 years - more of a range and much cleaner. Plenty of bars and restaurants for late night revellers. Am looking forwrad to seeing what will happen to this area over the next 5 years.

Scenic stroll, but very commercial. We walked the Harbour which was next to our hotel while we were waiting to check in. We also later picked up the ferry from here. There are pricey museums and restaurants abound, and lots of nightlife, but a bit commercial for my tastes.

Take your time and soak up the atmosphere. Wander slowly and leisurely to enjoy this site. Drop in to the Maritime museum. Enjoy the shops, food, people and sights. There is always something new to see every time I visit.

Great Multicultural Vibe. Darling Harbour on a weekend is a busy place. It is fantastic to see so many adults and children, both local and tourists, from so many ethnic and religious backgrounds enjoying the sun, street performers, play equipment, attractions, food etc, it has a fantastic atmosphere and really should not be missed, especially if you have children, on a trip to Sydney.At the moment there is a rather large (about 40 feet high) yellow rubber duck sitting in the water, we can't tell you why but did overhear someone saying it was art! Anyway, it is going to appear in holiday photo's from people all over the world as there were hundreds of people taking shots of it at any one time.
The Ugly Duckling. The area was nothing but dilapidated warehouses and woolsheds. The transformation in the last 15 years has changed the area into a beautiful swan.

Lovely area!. We were amazed at how large of an area Darling Harbour was. We were able to walk all around and look in the shops, stop for a drink in one of the cafes and people watch! There's even a playground for the children.
Too Touristy. Lots of restaurants but some are quite tacky and the whole area is way too touristy for me. Long queues for dinner at 8pm on a Sunday do not go down well. Great for breakfasts though.

So much to see and do!. Probably my most visited part of Sydney, there is just so much to do! Loads of great places to eat, Madam Tussauds, Sydney Aquarium, Sydney Zoo, Imax cinema, Maritime museum, Chinese gardens, plus shopping centre and boat trips. If you go to Darling Harbour try to walk there through China town (or visit China town which is very near by). There is also a childrens play park with fair ground rides and beautiful fountains where on hot days children can swim and splash about. There are shady areas surrounded by grass where lots of people go for picnics.

great for the family. spent some time in darling harbour during our recent visit with family. while prices for everything are inflated it is designed for the family. we met up with family and had 3 small children with us and they had a ball. plenty of things for the kids to do and adults can take a breather. if you have kids with you this is a must go zone.
Brilliant Atmosphere. Darling Harbour is great for the fireworks, nights out (bungalow 8),culture (maritime museum) and dinner! not to be missed!
A manufactured attraction. This was supposed to be vibrant and lively like Baltimore (its inspiration), but somebody lost the plot along the way. You can do better.

Expensive, crowded and lacks rubbish bins. Lunch here was expensive I assume this is because the rent is high given the location Be careful when dining ....if they ask you if you want 'still water' be prepared that it's still bottled water. Had a nice surprise when we were charged $13.50 for a bottle of San Pellegrino because we said we wanted still water. I was later told when in Sydney and you're dining out, if you want tap water, you need to ask for it so that there's no confusion Kids got an ice cream but we struggled to find bins There are a few public bins but not enough for the amount of people in the area. This concerns me. No wonder the harbour is spoilt by the amount of litter that makes its way into the water Choose the day and time you visit. We visited in Jan 2013 on a Sunday around lunchtime. It was very busy. Photo ops are difficult under such crowded conditions. I would revisit late in the afternoon or early morning to avoid crowds
Easy walking territory. Darling Harbour is filled with families because it is like the lungs of the city. Salt air. Places to sit and just watch people go by.

Family friendly all year. Darling Harbour is always busy as there's so much to see and do all year round for the whole family. We've been too many times to count, but it never gets boring! Everything from free entertainment to various museums and other attractions are surrounded by many restaurants, cafes and shops. The monorail passes overhead (not for much longer though, as it's been sold and is due to be dismantled) and all types of watercraft come in and out the harbour .. a bonus is to see the Pyrmont Bridge open when a larger boat has to enter. There's playgrounds for the kids and often themed attractions during festival times. Parking and accommodation are both available but the prices can be expensive. A visit to Sydney is not complete without seeing Darling Harbour.

The ultimate place to be with children on a hot day!. Darling Harbour has a good selection of restaurants and pay-for attractions, but I really just wanted to highlight the fabulous (and free) children's play area. Lots of swings, slides, climbing things and a lovely large water play area with fountains and also 'rivers' that can be controlled by the children via sluice gates and movable dams. There is something to keep all ages of children from 1 to around 12 happy and entertained.

Darling Harbour. What a wonderful area - such fun to walk around. There is just about every kind of restaurant you could ask for, plus some shops and there always seemed to be some activity going on in the water. We spent several evenings walking around here as it is obviously the place to be for young and old alike. We lucked out to see Santa arriving with his reindeer on the water followed by a firework display - a wonderful conclusion to our visit to Sydney. Definitely a must place to visit when in Sydney.

Having fun at day time, romantic at night time. Wow, go with friends in day time, spend your time enjoy lunch or coffee time, very relax, best !!Want to spend the romantic dinner or walking with your love one at the harbour ?. Here is the right places

Give Margaritaville a Miss!!!/The Harbour Is Worth The Visit. We loved the location, lots of restaurants to choose from. We made a mistake choosing Jimmy Buffett's diner.(Margaritaville). The drinks were "outrageously" expensive..........$20.00 for a Margarita??? We ordered beer. not because we couldn't afford a Magarita, but we just don't like being "gouged"!! My coconut shrimp was so overdone, it was unrecognizable as shrimp. Inedible. We were three grown women. We were seated at a lovely table overlooking the harbour. this was an inside table as the outdoor tables were all taken. Within fifteen minutes we were "surrounded" by screaming children, the hosts having seated three families all around us. To say our meal was ruined would be an understatement. I LOVE children, but it was poor judgement to do that to us. We have the right to enjoy our meal, as much as the next person. The proper thing to do, would have been to offer us a table "outside" as one became available. Not to subject us to a kindergarten setting in the first few minutes of being seated!!

great for kids. Although we didnt have kids with us, we could see that this was a great place for them. There are plenty of restaurants here, although the service was not the best in the one that we went to!

Lots of wonderful shops and restaurants. Darling was all lit up for Christmas when I visited, complete with carollers' singing! Lots of great restaurants in Darling Harbour and a large variety of different places to shop.

Sydney Aquarium. Well worth the cost. The attractions were of high standards and the exhibits were all informative and interesting. It took over an hour to see all the sea life from all over Australia.Highly recommend for all the family to see.

my fave. this Harbour is one of the best in Australia, it is packed with Cafes on right and left so it is also packed with people and always busy with entertainment. a lots of freebies there such as fireworks on weekends and street artists days and nights. if you are on a budget or ready to blow your pocket, this place is for everyone.

Liveliest of the tourist destinations.. Always plent going on an a great area to take the kids so that they can let off a bit of steam in the children's play area. That play area is one of the most elaborate and safest FREE children's playgrounds that I've ever seen.
Good location and a lot to do. Good touristic place with a lot of (some very good) Restaurants and Bars. A MUST GO when you are in Sydney, probably best in the evening.
need to visit it. great food,navl museum s must if u r there with childrens .jet boating ,evening dinner cruise etc are great.

Giant Rubber Duck. My fiance and I went to the Darling Harbor to check out the Giant Rubber Duck from Sydney Festival. I thought it was such a fun experience for all ages. It's a beautiful harbor- a bit touristy but that is what it is there for. We didn't stop at any of the restaurants but we did walk around and enjoy the view.
Touristy but alive and kicking!. We had a great afternoon, the docks are great to walk around, the restaurants are abundant. A great place to put on the list while visiting Sydney.
Nice afternoon. Great trip with a bus from Bondi to Circular Quay, ferry to Darling Harbour, visits to the zoo and aquarium - a lovely way to spend a summer afternoon.
pleasant pedestrianised area. pleasant pedestrianised area with eating places, shops, monorail access and attractions for children.

Go at night!. Darling Harbor is a great place for dinner and drinks. Busy without being annoying, it's filled with restaurants, cafes, shops, bars, etc. Take your loved one and go for a romantic stroll in one of the most beautiful cities in the world. You can't go to Sydney and not visit Darling Harbor. A must!

Tourist trap. Similar to Navy Pier or South Street seaport, it's a pretty bug tourist trap. Sydney Harbour is much more beautiful! Avoid Sea Life and Wild Life. Too many poorly behaved children, sad animals and annoying tourists.

See the huge duck in January!. As part of the Sydney festival, there's a 5 story tall rubber duck floating in the harbor that is pretty fun to see. I think it's there thru the end of January. There are numerous attractions in this area and it's a good place to catch a sightseeing boat for a couple of hours to tour the Sydney harbor. You can also find a couple of fountains worth looking at and plentiful restaurants. Great spot!

Carol & Malcolm's retirement trip.. Just to say we did it, we got on the monorail out to Darling Harbour. Bought a 'Big tkt.'and visited the Maritime museum and then did the tour on the Destroyer HMAS Vampire,the Submarine HMAS Onslow and the fantastic replica of Capt. Cooks HMB Endeavour, well worth the visit,all ameneties available.

Still a great place to visit.. Our family was at Darling Harbour for the New Year period and so we spent a lot of time wandering around and having a good look at things again. at the shopping precinct is really only for tourists as thats what the shops all mainly sell, souveniers. Which is a shame as there are still a lot of people like our party who don't want to buy that type of thing. The food court was packed and people waiting around like vultures for you to leave so that they can pounce into your space. Its OK if thats what you like but I would prefer a little time to converse with others and eat your selections - which really aren't any typical Australian foods for tourists to try. - you would think that they would have some typical Australian food like a Bar BQ (the smell of a bar bq cooking is unbelievale and would soon draw in the mouth watering crowds or Harry's pies etc However the grounds, street entertainment, the cool places and water displays are fantastic and a very welcome spot on a day as hot as it was the day that we were there. It was also great to see a new entertainment arrive and that was a gigantic yellow duckie. Our visit here was very hot, crowded and not many places to sit but it was still great to walk around and do some site-seeing in. Just remember to take the block-out and a hat because ouside its hot and you could easily get burnt. We were parked in the parking station which made it easy, although you can also get there by the monorail or the light rail train going to the casino and the train stops are fairly close to the harbour and entertainment areas.

even for a sydneysider it's great. I used to shun darling harbour as being just a tourist spot. but with a small child I've started to really enjoy the place. From the Santa on waterski's during christmas time to the saturday evening fireworks every week in summer. the restaurants are pretty good and varied and there's always stuff to see and do.
so much to do. The kids and i never get sick of Darling Harbour! so many activities and new things to do! Great atmosphere and loved the aquarium!
Beautiful Harbour with lots of Amenities. Plenty to do down on the Harbour. Lots of Restaurants, the IMAX cinema, Aquairum, Waxworks. Chinese Gardens, China Town and lots more

For the tourist. But in the end, I'm a tourist...so, went there 2 times to have lunch and dinner with fireworks on saturday night. It was News Years Holidays so the city was packed with lots of tourist and lines everywhere. As a Four Points guest, I have the lovely view of the Harbour right in my window.

Chill Out!. Fantastic venue, eveything you could want for a day/evening out.
Views, shopping, bars, restaurants, parkland, children's facilities, pleasure cruises, secluded gardens.
Something for every age group.
Fun day out!. We are from Sydney but love Darling Harbour. Easy accessible ad lots to do. Great views, fantastic places to eat, IMAX theatre and ferries are great

Loved Darling Harbor!. We were the only passengers on a Sydney Harbor Eco Hopper from the Circular Quay to Darling Harbor (which was amazing!) There were so many shops and restaurants and places to see and do: The Sea Life Aquarium, Madam Tussauds, the Maritime Museum, the Imax theater..and much more! But we were there for the Wildlife Zoo and to go to Hardrock Cafe--both of which were great! I would have loved to have spent more time at Darling Harbor! Take time to go to the shops and restaurants there!

Inner city variety on the harbour. Darling Harbour has something for everyone. The kids will love the play areas; there's the serenity of the garden area and entertainining fountains and pools. The monorail and water taxis service the area, with Chinatown just a walk away.A popular conference and exhibition area, Darking Harbour has some covenient hotels and lots of shops, restaurants and bars,too.

A world of entertainment for adults and the kids. Like the title says, Darling Harbour has it all. From iMAX movies and the plethora of bars, clubs and restaurants, to the children's playgrounds involving swings, flying foxes and spider crawling, there is fun and entertainment for everyone. Walking up Darling Harbour and stop just outside the iMAX, you'll see a notice board which has a handy list of upcoming events and entertainment for the current and upcoming month.This is great when planning a weekend out with friends, or with that special someone. There is often a large sample of cultural activities - from Brazilian dancing to Korean food tasting - so it is likely to please everyone involved!5 stars for the services and family oriented atmosphere that is provided.

Atmosphere - day and night. I walked around here a couple of times during my Sydney stay. In the day time there is a lovely buzz and children play in the brilliant park and water features.At night the atmosphere is vibrant. The place was packed but there were still places to sit or sights to take in and street performances to enjoy.On Saturday nights - there are the fireworks - don't miss them!

So much to do at Darling Harbour. A must do is the Maritime Museum - amazing. What a way to spend a day, but even if that's not your thing, there's loads of bars and restaurants and other stuff to do. Unfortunately the weather wasn't great, but that didn't ruin a thing, loads to do and expect sore feet at the end of the day with the amount of walking you'll do!
Lots to see. Many different bars, restaurants and things and places to see - just a short walk from George Street in the CBD so well worth a visit by anyone in Sydney for the first time.

The city view is great in this location. We always go to Darling Harbour very often. After our lunches at Chinatown, we go for coffee and cakes here. The Lindt coffee shop is the best for eclairs and coffee. There is so much to do in this area. Museums are close by. Strolling and people watching are a must.

Great place. So much to do with my family of 6, undoubtedly the most popular place for my teen children. The IMAX, the Maritime museum, a Hard Rock Cafe, the aquarium...so much to do. Would definitely recommend spending some time at Darling Harbour.

Summer Fireworks were fabulous - what an atmosphere. I went in on Saturday night for the fireworks with my seven year old and a German visitor. It was entracing. The night was balmy and there was such a buzz about the place. The playground was still filled which children having fun.The area was (comfortably) packed with people but really family friendly. The fireworks were great and the whole evening was the best of a Sydney summe rnight (finished with an ice cream of course).

Nightlife. We ate at Nicos Fish Bar - good food and service. We walked around the whole area and watched street entertainers and enjoyed the hustle and bustle of a busy night life. Varied places to eat and drink and overall not to be missed if you visit Sydney.

My favourite part of Sydney. Brilliant, I loved Darling Harbour, it has so much more than Sydney Harbour. We went on the Monorail, and then ate at one of the fab restaurants, the views were amazing, then we headed to Paddys Market were we shopped for a couple of hours. When I go back this will be the first place I head for.
a little Darling. What a beautiful harbour spent a full day there when we were in Sydney good shopping good food plenty of watering holes and a lovely walk around the harbour its self

Darling Harbour Playground - incl waterpark,flying fox, ropes & loads more!. We stumbled on this whilst walking around Darling Harbour and our daughter just loved it. Here is the info from their site: The Darling Quarter Kids Playground' is one of the most spectacular ever built in Australia, featuring an array of fun activities that promote learning and imagination for all ages. Water games, climbing ropes, swings, slides, and a flying fox will keep the kids entertained for hours. All free' http://www.darlingquarter.com/playParents: there are ample places for you to get your coffee too.
great places. Maritime museum and the various ships were really great to see. Just near Chinatown and covered in nice restaurants. Excellent views and really easy ferry access to everywhere.

One of the world's special places.... A simply amazing place - by day a chilled vibe around this beautiful wharf, harbour, full of bars and restaurants (some amazing - see later reviews), smell of the sea of you walk around admiring the boats, buildings, people, and places. By night amazing skyline views, a buzz of excitement, a playground for the young & older, smells of delicious food, sounds of street entertainers, and parties of friends & family enjoying themselves. As if that wasn't enough there is the perfect kids park next door, a wonderful adventure playground perfect for younger & slightly older kids, an outdoor cinema at night showing free films, surrounded by yet more bars and restaurants. And all this just moments from the central city - a very special place indeed - please do visit!

Getting Better !. Last time we were here we wondered what all the fuss was about. Its now heaps better with plenty of bars & restaurants, Aquarium, Imax cinema etc & some good hotels. Be warned - this becomes "party central" at the weekend & gets very lively !

Amazing fireworks!. More than 20 restaurants and bars occupy the Harbour and on specific Saturdays across the year they have the most amazing fireworks at 9 p.m. It was Saturday night and Darling Harbour was filled with people waiting for the fireworks. When it started it was amazing. The night became day again. For approximately 15-20 minutes every possible shape and color lighted the sky. It was like new years eve! Don't miss it.

Worth a visit. We spent a few hours walking around the harbour and had a pleasant lunch at Rosati's Restaurant. We had a relaxing time and were able to look at potential activities for future days. We did go back to vist the acquarium, see separate review.

A lovely experience. Getting here by ferry from Sydney Harbour and then going around to see the Wildlife World and the Aquarium. There are not enough words to describe the experience of the Aquarium....brilliant concept, brilliantly executed...
must see!. Darling Harbour is where you will see the aquarium etc. Lots of interesting places to explore and eateries galore. Chinese Gardens also in the area

Great day and night!. Darling Harbour is a great place to visit day or night. Great restaurants, views and shopping. Catch a ferry from here to head to the Zoo. Just near IMAX is a great play area for kids (or those young at heart).
Great spot with lots to do and see.. Great spot for walking, shopping and eating. Lots to do and see, from restaurants, to jet boat rides, to catching a ferry, the aquarium and the list goes on.
Darling Harbour. A bit of a hike from Sydney Harbour, but easy to reach by Hop-on/Hop-off Bus or Ferry. This is where the aquarium is, and it's well worth seeing. Also good restaurants & shops.

The sun's shining get out there.... We stayed close to Darling harbour and found some of it by accident, the restaurants and cafes are great, free wifi is brilliant even in the middle of the recreation area, and my kids personal favourite was the water and play park. If it had been a little warmer my girls would have happily spent half a day playing in the water. From an adult perspective, this is a beautiful place, most amazed by the huge circular water feature that is over near the shopping mall. If you need somewhere a little "less expensive" to eat try the food hall in the shopping mall, really tasty oriental cuisine.
Buzzing with atmosphere. Always something to see, even the yellow duck in the harbour. A good place for a stroll at any time of the day.
Darling Harbour. I like Darling harbour because it has everything you want to go and see, shopping areas and foods..you will also see the Darling Quarter, a place to go with your family esp kids..
Pleasant break. We stayed here for three days over New Year,had a wonderful time wandering around the Harbour three days wasn't long enough

Pretty Harbour lots of restaurants. Well, if you can eat a lot this is a fun place! But, mostly it is a tiny harbour lined by many, many restaurants and a small mall. That's about it. Pretty scenery though . . .

Tourist restaurants and not much else. It's difficult to understand why people go to Darling Harbour other than because they think they should. It's basically a wharf with a wide walkway and a 'train' being driven along its length. There are the usual Merlin Group attractions and, apart from that, loads of restaurants and not much else.
Great selection of restaurants. This is a great area of Sydney that is very vibrant with activity and great places to sit and eat and drink, or to undertake other activities
A must do.. It's a buzz with people, activity, water, music. Harbour cruised from here worthwhile, try the "rythem boat" for some fun and entertainment.
Great for kids. Visited on Sunday. The place was full. Lots of kids playing. Highly recommended if you are visiting with kids.

Dated and expensive. This place looks like a throwback from the 80s - in particular the Convention Centre, which needs to be pulled down. The "Harbourside" shopping centre is also very tacky. The restaurants here are generally very poor and incredibly overpriced - do your research online before eating here.
On the plus side, it's nice for photos and kids enjoy it.

unique. we enjoyed our day here, the place is busy with a broad scope of tourists & locals. The entertainment is colorful and there are many attractions to fit all budgets. There are also many places to eat that apeal to all food tastes.

Stayed on the harbour and loved it. What a great place to walk around, sit at the cafes and bars and just chill out. I had a lovely hotel room and walked the darling harbour most days to get into the city or took the monorail

New play area at Darling Harbour/Quarter. On a recent visit to Darling Harbour, we came across a new Play Area in the area they call Darling Quarter. It is quite different and our kids hadnt seen anything like it before. There is a big rock/water play area with pumps, water buckets, bridges etc. The kids played there for ages. It also had several different sized slippery slides, a flying fox and climbing gym. There were also water spouts so if you didnt mind the kids getting wet (or better still had their swimmers!) it would be even more fun. Best of all its free, and the parents can sit and watch the world go by while the kids have some free fun!
lost of restaurants & bars. Beautiful at night in Summer. Plenty of bars & restaurants to choose from. Lots of variety, just a great place.

Fantastic food venues. Visited darling harbor twice while we were in Sydney to eat and look around. Had dinner at the meat and wine co (see my separate review) and had lunch at cure. Took the hop-on-hop off down there both times in our 24 window and love it both times

Must do place!. Loved loved loved Darling Harbour. Great for shopping, eating and sitting watching the world go by. When the sun goes down and the lights come on its even more beautiful and I would especially recommend sitting outside sipping a cocktail in anyone of the great bars available. We sat out even when it rained it was that good!

Great spot, much more relaxed than Circular Quay. A beautiful and relaxing spot with lots of great restaurants, cafes and attractions. Much more low key than Circular Quay if you want a quieter spot. Loved it here.
Fun family outing. Fun for the whole family. Lots of restaurants to choose from and a beautiful scenery to soak. Check out the boat museum. The kids will love the pirate ships!
Great water-front, lots of restaurants. We came here to eat lunch and also to take a sailboat cruise. Clean, organized, a bit less crazy than Crcular Quai

A great spot for wining and dining. Loved being in a beautiful location, felt like we were in the heartbeat of Sydney. Lots of places to eat and drink, access to boat rides to the Harbour and plenty of places to just sit and take it all in!
tourist central. wax museums to restaurants... hard rock cafe... casinos...great boardwalk to walk on ... take the monorail for a spin.
Something for everyone. Many attractions and shows to see around the harbour together with restaurants people watching, easy to get to from Circular Quay, downtown area.

Great day trip. Make sure to get here during your time in Sydney. Best thing to do is take a ferry from Circular Quay. Also make sure to book your restaurant in advance. There are lots of boring restaurants that you'll see walking around, but there are several AMAZINGLY delightful eating venues but these tend to be either on a higher floor or a few streets over. You'll be very glad for doing a bit of research in advance (i.e. eating at Malaya or Medusa's Greek Tavera will make your taste buds rejoice).
A bit over priced. Slightly tired looking but still worth a visit. Prices are aimed at tourists but worth a look if the sales are on.Parking was $24 for 2 hours though!!
Nothing special. Darling Harbour was nothing special, just a few sailing boats and restaurants around the Harbour. Maybe worth a visit since everyone talks about it, but really nothing there.

.....nice but a little tired!. Having visited Darling Harbour many times over the years and for a variety of reasons, my family and I found it to be somewhat tired this visit. In saying, there are still some exciting 'eating houses' and feel certain that with a 'facelift' it could become the exciting venue it was known to be.
darling of Sydney. I loved every bit of this beautiful place. It is the hub of Sydney and still plesant to walk around. We saw the New Yeaes Fireworks from here and it was magnificent

scenic and beautiful. beautiful when gloomy. extraordinary when sunny. i loved walking/running around the harbour while in sydney. grab a coffee and just sit down along the harbour. don't bother with the expensive restaurants along the harbour though--they're expensive and not that great.

Lots to see and do for all the family. Take the ferry from central Sydney to Darling Harbour and you will not be disappointed with the views of the city. Spend the time to walk around the area and look at the attractions and choose a nice spot to dine - A good area for a half day excursion.

Love NYE at Darling Harbour. Fantastic fireworks without the massive crowds seen at Circular Quay. Alcohol free so very family friendly. Maritime area is fantastic for kids but allow a whole day to do everything on offer if it is school holidays
Darling Harbour. VIBRANT...the place to go, day or night...try and get to the Saturday night fireworks...excellent !!

Pleasant as part of a walk. We included Darling Harbour as part of our afternoon walk. It was pleasant enough as part of a walk and fun walking around the outside of the Australian National Maritime Museum. I wouldn't condider it a 'must see' though; I preferred Circular Quay.

Darling Harbour. If you like history, as iI do, there is plenty to see and do at Darling Harbour. The Maritime Museum Museum is excellent and gives you details of early settlement by European settlers and Australian native peoples who lived in what is now the Sydney area.

Lots to look at around Darling Harbour!. We enjoyed wandering around the harbour. There are many water fountain areas, boats, restaurants and shops. Many of the shops are in behind the restaurants, so you can't actually see them from the harbour sidewalks. We had difficulty choosing a restaurant as there were quite a few that appealed to us. Several of them were trying to encourage customers to eat early (between 5 and 7pm) by offering specials during those hours. Very clean, and not smelly as some harbours can be.
Iconic. We were in Darling Harbour the day of the Melbourne Cup. There were parties going on all over. There was such joy and excitement. You must visit the Maritime Museum too. Fabulous

Overrated. Darling Harbour is pleasant, a 'must see' when in Sydney(so all the guidebooks say) but don't expect something out of the ordinary. It's a modern harbour, very clean, lots of places to have coffee or eat but as for 'views' you just look out onto a modern quay with hotels, nothing spectacular but somewhere to kill an hour or two. Certainly wouldn't want to visit again. There are some nice attractions for kiddies over on one corner and some nice little gardens, probably the nicest part.

Good Day Out. Took the family here, and they really enjoyed. Great choice of dining on the harbour. Places for the whole family. If you want to soak up a bit of the atmosphere grab a table at one of the many bars and watch the world go by

Darling Habor. The ferry ride from Luna Park at the end of the Bridge Walk was fun. While the harbor is filled with large scale chain restaurants, we were there for the fireworks. It's a very good visit if there are fireworks. I didn't see anything there otherwise worth a special visit. better food around the Circular Quay and The Rocks.
Nice place for a walk. The harbor was near our hotel and a nice scenic place for a stroll with a park nearby leading to China town. No view of the Opera house or Sydney bridge from here.
Great for families. Lots of choices for breakfast, lunch or dinner, plenty to see and do. Close to the CBD but so different being on the water
A great place to sit and relax. Or indeed a great place to walk. It was very busy here but we walked all the way round via the Pyrmont bridge to get a great view of it all.
Feels as new as it is. I am sure this will soon become a major attraction but it is still so new it has yet to obtain the warmth of the main harbour.

Something for Everyone. We had several meals at Darling Harbour and visited everyday. (Almost to the embarassing stage). Lovely place to walk around. Great gardens and playground (pity I didn't have young children). Easy walk to the market.

Great atmosphere. Great energy.. This is a must see place while in Sydney. It is always crowded but it just makes it more fun. The energy is great. There are all kinds of restaurants along the strip, and there are also several food courts around as well. It is one block away from The Star (the main casino in Sydney) and also one block away the other way from Chinatown. So you get the point.
Very Kid Friendly. Love the new play area for the kids however one drawback was that there seemed to be very little bathroom services available.

I love this place. Great place for families and couples. A multitude of restaurants, galleries, museums and many other attractions makes this a great place to spend time in Sydney. Keep in mind that this place is priced for tourists and those celebrating so the prices can be a bit high. I love buying an icecream and sitting on the steps of the harbour watching the world go by.
Greta harbour. Cool little tourist harbour. Much quieter than Sydney harbour with a good selection of cafes/restaurants. Plenty of tourist attractions within walking distance

Plenty to see and do. The harbour is in itself pretty and there is so much to around with the aquarium, museums, Chinese Gardens, Harbour park and water gardens. If you want to eat or drink then there are bars and food galore
Ok, but not great. ok with plenty of bars and restaurants but does seem a bit to tacky with lots of chain bars and restaurants

Enjoy it while you can. Yes Darling Harbour is getting a bit tacky but am not sure if it is worth completely redeveloping as the NSW Government intend to do. There are great shops and restaurants and nice scenic walks around Darling Harbour. On a rainy Christmas Day it seemed a pleasant haven for heaps of backpackers and tourists.
Enjoyable walk, great for kids.. This area has lots of attractions for families with children, including climbable art. A great way to start exploration of the city if you have children in tow.

Heaps of activity. We spend a lot of time here. There is plenty of shopping and eating at the Harbourside Mall. Just outside the mall is a clock-like fountain you can walk down if your feet get hot and tired. Beyond the fountain, there is usually a street show going on like a dance troupe, musicians, magic shows, etc. Around the corner from the Starbucks and Imax is Tumbalong park, which has one of Sydney's greatest playgrounds. Though it can get quite crowded and the wait for certain attractions is chaotic, it's still worth visiting if you go early and during the week. The Sydney Sea Life Aquarium has undergone many updates and Sydney Wildlife is a nice place for a rainy day. I wouldn't pay the price of admission alone here, but if you buy it as part of a bundle, it is a good value. The bundles include admission to Sea Life, Madame Tussaud's wax museum, Sydney Wildlife, the Manly aquarium, the Sydney Tower, and some attraction in another state. Also in Darling Harbour is the Australian Maritime Museum. I just yawned typing that, but we only went to get out of the rain. They do have (fun?) exhibitions during school holidays and you can tour a submarine, and old schooner, and a naval ship, but the price is pretty steep if you're bringing the whole family. On a side note, the best way to get here is by ferry, but it's also accessible by bus, lightrail, and monorail.

One of many beautiful harbors. What can you say about Sydney? One harbor after another and all of them grand! From the beautiful homes on the water to the bridge and Opera House, it is a trip worth repeating.

Great spot for kids and adults. They have the best kids interactive water play area I've seen, I wanted my togs to play to. Beaut area for adults especially on the weekends when there is so much going on and so much to watch.
Eat before you visit.. Beautiful but overpriced, awesome place to people-watch. The Aquarium is a must-do and an OK price, we spent about 3 hours there, closing times vary so check before you go.

Great food area. Plenty to see and lots of great eating places at reasonable prices.
Lots of things happening there.Not much to dislike.
Pretty touristy. Darling Harbour is pretty touristy and the restaurants were pricey. We did better in other parts of the city.
Christmas in Sydney. Sydney was beautiful at Christmas time. Great location, food, atmosphere.Lots of great bars and restaurants all around. Great views. Recommend Umi sushi.

great fun. watch where your carpark empties out onto Darling Harbor so you can find it again when you return. Has cheap food court to eat it and overpriced view restaurants such as Chyren to waste your money on. Wonderful IMAX theater and excellent Austalian Maritime Museum. Worth the money. I didn't see the aquarium but am sure that would be good too. Great for the kids.

So much to see and do. Darling Harbour has so many different attractions you can visit time and again and always find something to do. On the weekend I was there, they had Dragonboat racing in the harbour itself and a festival in the park. There are lots of restaurants and cafes catering to all budgets. You can take the ferry to other parts of the harbour or walk into the city centre.

Festive and yet family-friendly. Plenty of nice scenery and activities for kids and family, and plently of food options too. Nice place to bring your young ones, either to its huge playground or to several paid-attractions (aquarium, wildlife park, etc).

Wonderful place to walk to. Our hotel was only 5 minutes away so we went there all the time.The harbor is clean and safe. It has many nice places to eat and several places to visit like the animal zoo which we enjoyed.We picked up the ferry every day in the morning and rode it around the Sydney Harbour. A great way to start the day.

Love the harbour. It's all there in one place - maritime museum (pirate experience for the kids), ferry rides to the zoo, aquarium, monorail to paddy's markets (for now), great food and a shopping centre.

2 nights on Darling Harbour. Spent 2 nights on Darling Harbour at the Ibis and we walked around this whole area. Many restaurants to choose from, Imax Theatre, caught ferry to Circular Quay; This gave us a good opportunity to look and walk around this area and found it very relaxing and enjoyable.

Love this place. So much to do around the harbour for both big and little kiddos. You are spoilt for choice for dining. It is all kept very clean and the childrens play area was a huge hit. Cant wait to go back.

Not to be missed. This seems to be the entertainment area. Very close to the Star Theatre where all the major shows are performed, so a great place to eat before or after the show. Lots of bars and restaurants to go to and from here you have a great view of the city.
GREAT PLACE. Great place to base your self .... Good Restaurants, Good shopping and good accommodation. Next time Im back would def stay here again.

"Beautiful View". Visited Sydney during our stay in Australia, and I'm glad we did as we were able to visit the Harbour, Opera house and go on an amazing "hop on hop off' boat ride too. It was exciting passing the nudist beaches too something we do not see too often. I enjoyed the view with with all the boats just swaying at sea and the seagulls. Also the Military ship and bridge at the background is a sight for visitors to see. Also saw Captain Cooks ship. We also saw the Australian Maritime Museum and last but not least visited Bondi Beach late in the evening.A very busy place with visitors and locals mixing having so much fun and so many places to have good food and enjoy a cool beer too. It was very tiring having to see all these places in a day but fully worth the trip, and we are glad we did.

Our favorite spot in Sydney. There's just so much lives in Darling Harbor! With the Sydney city skyline as backdrop, not only is Darling Harbor a excellent choice for photographers, but it's also so near to all shopping options, from Chinatown to QVB to Westfield ... and with the romantic harbor view, it's always an excellent choice to take your love ones here to dine in one of those impressive restaurants along the Cockle Bay Wharf.

Beautiful, day or night!. Grab a coffee, an ice cream, sit by the Harbour, watch and hear the boats, the seagulls and the world go by. Great photo taking opportunity, with the Australian Military ship in the background, or the lighthouse, or simply the water-view and the high rise buildings. It's a cool summer, so I liked the chilly breeze at daytime. You will also find many eateries and Harbourside mall to shop at. Wildlife and the Sealife Aquarium is also situated by the Harbour. Catch a ferry, buy some souvenirs and by night, watch the Harbour lit up with beautiful lights. This Dec, there's fireworks every Saturday night. Reminds me of Clarke Quay back home, but the walkway is much more spacious at Darling Harbour. Gives decent space for a good stroll.

People watching. This is a great place to just sit and people watch. Loads of restaurants and cafes of all prices. I think the shopping area has gone downhill since I first starts going 12 years ago. Sued to be loads of Australian made goods and now it is mostly Chinese made goods. We went for the small train ride round the harbour and enjoyed it. Great park for the kids to play with water spouts good on a hot day
Great Food and Entertainment. Darling Harbour has been populated by numerous eateries and bars, as well as shopping areas. It's a very pleasant place to spend a day, week, life...

Loved this place. After a city of shakes that now has limited nightlife, Darling Harbour was all go. Thousands there on Saturday night for the fireworks including many children - which was fabulous they were somewhere safe watching all the action. Loads of bars and buskers. Great for a weekend.

Wow!!. Darling Harbor was a short walk from Chinatown--our original destination. The most enjoyable sight in Sydney--and the least expected was our encounter with the Chinese Friendship Garden. This was a never-ending visual feast of beautifully landscaped vistas with a brief introduction, either by sight (a wall opening or moon gate) or sound (falling water), to a continually changing view. This, we agreed, was the highlight of our visit to Sydney. Avoid riding the small tractor-driven train ride around the harbor unless you have a very strong back--walk it instead. There are a plethora of shops, restaurants, and the Sydney Exhibition Center and Convention Center, plus an unusual children's play park here.
